LIMERICK, Sept. 5.--There have been further riots here during the morning. Soldiers who marched upon George-street were stoned. They then charged the mob, dispersing it in all directions.

The party interests of the English Conservatives are being badly managed under the present dual leadership. There is such a general distrust of Lord SALISBURY'S powers as an organizer and tactician that the control of the party has never been unreservedly committed to him, Sir STAFFORD NORTHCOTE being in many quarters regarded as the more capable man of the two.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5.--The Cincinnati Sink-- ing Fund Commissioners met this afternoon to act on the lease of the Southern Railroad by the Trustees to Frederick Wolffe. Two of the Commissioners were in favor of confirming the lease at once, but the others desired to be satisfied that Wolffe is the representative of the Erlanger interest, and its consideration was postponed until Wednesday.

WILKESBARE, Penn., Sept.5.--The funeral of Hendrick B. Wright took place at 5 o'clock this afternoon. Bishop Stevens, of Philadelphia, assisted by the Rev. Mr. Hayden, of this city, and the Rev. Mr. Williams, of Pittsburg, conducted the services. An immense throng of people were in attendance.
The September moon fulls on the 7th. She is in conjunction with Saturn and Neptune on the 12th; with Jupiter on the 13th, and with Mars on the 15th, passing one degree and a quarter to the north.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 5.--A McMinnville special to the Banner says that during a difficulty between T. J. R. Swifford and Eli Paul, at Sparta, Swifford shot and killed paul and severely wounded one of Paul's sons, who was endeavoring to protect his father. James Scott, father-in-law of Swifford, was also killed. Scott was trying to separate the combatants.
LONG BRANCH, Sept. 5.--If President Garfield does not reach Elberon before daylight to-morrow morning he will find nothing lacking for his comfort and convenience when he does come.

An adjourned meeting of the Police Justices was held last night in the Jefferson Market Court-house, Justice Otterbourg presiding. The latter explained the details of an interview that he had had with the representative of District Attorney Rollins respecting certain provisions of the new code, and announced that a further conference on the subject would be held on the return of the District Attorney.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 5.--The mysterious disappearance of a well-known and highly connected widow lady, who left her home in James City County Aug. 10, has awakened wide-spread interest.

A report was circulated that Mr. Coleman, Superintendent of the Street-cleaning Department, had given to Messrs. Nugent and Keenan the privilege of collecting at the dumps old bottles, metals, , although responsible parties had offered to pay the City $5,000 for that privilege.

PROSPECT HOUSE, NIAGARA FALLS, Ontario, Sept. 5.--About 3 o'clock this afternoon David Crimmins, of No. 69 Edward-street, Toronto, committed suicide by jumping over the Falls from the log projecting from Table Rock.
Mr. Coup's imposing circus and hippodrome will be introduced to the public to-night at the Madison-Square Garden.

RICHMOND, Sept. 5.--Thomas A. Marvin, alias Gen Budlong A. Mortan, in jail here awaiting trial, last evening appeared in a new role, and it was shown that his talents are by no manner of means confined to the accumulation of wives nor the manufacturing of spurious drafts.

A robbery occurred at the City National Bank Thursday, the particulars of which were kept very quiet during the day, and only leaked out testerday. It created much talk upon the streets, but as the facts could not be obtained from the bank officers, and it was difficult to find another relible source, little was known beyond the story told by rumor.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 23.--Your correspondent to-day places before the readers of the GlobeDemocrat a case which ere long will attract the attention of the whole country.

Dictator Pierola, of Peru, is a good traveler, and a determined one. During a period of five months he has made a journey, chiefly on the backs of mules and over rough Andean roads, of more than 550 leagues, and for nearly one-half that time he was stationed at Jauja recruiting an army.

No scientific person has as yet noticed the difference between the European and the American goat. The former never butts except under extreme provocation, and even then his blow is comparatively feeble.

A union meeting of various churches will be held in Plymouth Church, Brooklyn, this morning from 10 to 12 o'clock, at which prayers for the recovery of the President will be offered. The Pastors of several churches of different denominations are to participate in the services.

One of the longest sessions of Parliament in English history will terminate on Saturday. It is indeed amusing to compare its length, not only with that of former sessions, but of former Parliaments in their entirety.

OLEAN, N.Y., Sept.5.--A gentleman connected with the refining and pipe line interests of Buffalo, in speaking about the new petroleum trade organization, stated that the association was not formed for making an aggressive movement against the Standard Oil Company, but for protective interests and to elevate the price of crude and refined oil.

A meeting of furniture manufacturers was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Furniture Board of Trade, corner of Canal-street and Bowery, to oppose the strike of the upholsterers. Mr. J. W. Hamburger was elected Chairman.
Col. Polk, Secretary of the State Agricultural Society, yesterday received the following letter from Gen. Joseph E. Johnston:

Sister Louise, of the House of the Holy Comforter, at No. 54 West Eleventh-street, a free home for incurable women and children, appeals to the public for aid to meet the pressing wants of the institution. The funds are now so low that, except assistance in money and provisions be soon received, the helpless inmates will suffer.

NEUBOURG, Sept. 5.--M. Gambetta, speaking at a banquet last night, said he did not think it would be well to reopen the question of electoral reform immediately on the meeting of the new Chamber of Deputies; that it should not be abandoned, but only postponed, a fresh appeal to the country being unadvisable.

These amusing performers began their season last night at their cheerful theatre and received a cordial welcome. They need no introduction, for they have gained by their bright and interesting performances a permanent audience here.

The Summer vacation of the scholars in the public schools in this City terminated Saturday, and nearly all of the schools reopened yesterday for the Winter term. The only schools which did not open were Grammar Schools No.17, at No.335 West Forty-seventh-street, and No.60, at College-avenue and One Hundred and Forty-fifth-street.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Sept. 5.--The Bond Commission will not meet, according to adjournment, the decision of the Supreme Court on the questions of the issuance of a writ of prohibition and other weighty matters pertaining to the State railroad bonds, the Legislative provision for their payments,...

CINCINNATI, Sept. 5.--An effort has been made this afternoon to have the County Republican Convention, which is to meet at 10 o'clocK to-morrow, adjourned, for the reason that the day has been chosen by the Governor of the State as one of special prayer for the recovery of the President.
Broadway was thronged from Grand-street to Madison-square last evening by people who came to witness the torch-light parade of Coup's new united monster show.
The Conference of Baptist ministers of NewYork and vicinity met yesterday after a vacation of two months, The Rev. Dr. Thomas presided, and prayer was offered by the Rev. Dr. Osborne.

NEW-HAVEN, Sept. 5.--The arraignment to-day of Walter and James Malley Jr., on the charge of murdering Jennie Cramer, drew, a large number of people to Justice Booth's court-room. Many ladies were present.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--It has been a day of bustle and excitement in the White House. Everybody has been as busy packing up and preparing as though the entire Government was about to move in a body to Long Branch.
LONDON, Sept. 5.--The census of India has been completed. It shows a population of 252,500,000.
HAMBURG, Sept. 5.--The British ship Peter Young, Capt. Richau, which arrived here recently from Philadelphia, is aground in the river and is lightening. Her jibboom is broken.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 5.--The American Social Science Association began its annual session here this evening. The President, Prof. Francis Wayland, of the Yale Law School, delivered the annual address, which was quite long.

The most intense excitement was caused at the dock of the White Star Line, at the foot of West Tenth-street, yesterday afternoon by the report that two strange men had been seen to take a box on board the steamer Adriatic and soon after to depart without it.

Solomon De Pool, aged 5, son of Benjamin De Pool, an Israelite, born in Holland, who deals in alcohol at No. 104 Maiden-lane, ran away from No.354 West Thirty-ninth-street yesterday afternoon to play with some comrades.

One of the most curious arguments advanced by those who favor the repeal of the Lien law is that "the colored laborer does not possess an accurate knowledge of agriculture, and cannot profitably cultivate the soil." If the negro does not know how to farm, who does?

WASHINGTON, Sept. 5, 1881. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $107,000.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 5.--Dr. E. Lloyd Howard, Quarantine physician, and in charge of the Quarantine Hospital at this port for the past six years, was accidentally drowned in the harbor, at Commercial Wharf, this morning. He was on his board-...
Yesterday afternoon some young men were playing base-ball at Haledon, in the suburbs of Paterson, N. J. A young man named Tibby was at the bat and Benjamin Shorrock was pitching.

"The World," a melodrama which has been sufficiently described in these columns, was produced last night at Niblo's Garden. "The World" was a popular piece during its career at Wallack's Theatre, and it has been received with favor elsewhere. Its quality is that of the average sensational novel, and, outside of its single strong and valuable scene, it contains no element of real power, reality, or dramatic emotion.
LONDON, Sept. 5.--A dispatch from Quetta says : "On Aug. 31 Ayoob Khan issued a proclamation declaring that he had abandoned his intention of fighting the Ameer, and was about to fight the English.
TUNIS, Sept. 5.--The British gun-boats Bittern and Falcon have arrived at Goletta.

The Audran Opera Company, of which M. Defossez is the manager, gave its first performance last evening in the "Mascotte" at the Bijou Operahouse. The work is familiar to the regular theatregoer, and has deservedly been received with much favor.

Another new iron steam-ship, built for the Oregon Improvement Company by John Roach, of Chester, Penn., arrived at the Empire Stores, in Brooklyn, yesterday. She is named the Walla Walla, and will start in a few days for the Pacific coast with a cargo of railway material for the Oregon Improvement Company.

NEWPORT, Sept. 5.--Nearly 30 persons fol-- lowed the hounds this afternoon. The hunt was the best and last of the season. After eight miles had been covered the fox was run to death. Miss Hewitt, daughter of Congressman Hewitt, of New-York, was awarded the brush. The mask was given to Miss Bedlow, and the pads to George S. Browne, of Baltimore, and George Work, of New-York.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 5.--The following was transmitted this evening:

On Saturday morning Jacob Latus, of the firm of Latus Trautman, silk manufacturers in the Dale Mill, at Paterson, N. J., opposite the depot of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad, left Paterson and proceeded to New-York, telling his wife to have dinner ready for him at 1 o'clock in the afternoon, by which time he expected to return home.

Michael McAdams, the fellow who shot Thomas F. McConnell, Detective McConnell's son, on Sunday night, was arraigned at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday, and on a certificate from the surgeons at Roosevelt Hospital. Justice Smith committed him to await results.

The Rapid Transit Commission met again yesterday morning at 11 o'clock to consider plans for the newly laid out route in the annexed district. Commissioners De Graaf, Gerry, and Daly were present, and Commissioner De Graaf occupied the chair. Gen. Sickles came in later.

PHILADELPHIA Sept. 6.--In accordance with the proclamation of the Governor, the churches of the city were generally thrown open between the hours of 10 and 12 this morning for prayer for the recovery of President Garfield.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 6.--The Baltimore Elevator Company posted on 'Change in the morning the threatened notice of extra storage charges on grain in the blockaded Canton elevators. It had been feared that as high as 3 cents a bushel for every 10 days would be the charge.
DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 6.--The long-continued drought renders everything favorable for the running of fires in fields and woods, and these are inflicting immense damage.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 11.--Edward Cole, of New-York, was shot by Emanuel Gundaker, of this city, in the bar-room of the City Hotel, this evening. BALTIMORE, Sept. 14.--The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad to-day reduced its rates of passenger fare from this city to the West to correspond with the out rates from New-York. ROCHESTER, Sept. 27.--Wherever one may go in the State of New-York, he cannot avoid discovering, if he talk politics with men on the road, in towns or cities, that the Republicans are making their contests, preliminary to the State Convention, for the purpose of determining whether Conkling or his opponents shall rule in the political councils of the party.

The second day of the meeting of the American Jockey Club was but moderately attended, althongh the programme was attractive with its six races. The club-house and bluff were deserted, is on the previous day.

Lyne, a mechanical expert, has been making some experiments with the safetyvalve of Bulman Brown's boiler, which, exploding on the morning of Sept. 13, made a flying trip from the dry-Books at the foot of Essex-street to a point 1,000 feet up the street, killing two men and injuring several other.

WARSAW, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The Wyoming County Republican delegates, accompanied by Lieut.-Gov. Hoskins, left here for New-York to-night. The delegates are instructed to use all honorable means to promote harmony.

CORK, Oct. 3.--At a banquet here Father Sheehy announced that, unless all the prisoners under the Coercion act were released within a month, he intended to assemble all the delegates to the Land League from County Limerick and pledge them to withhold the payment of rents.

NEW-LEXINGTON, Ohio, Sept. 29.--The late President has relatives living in this town, Samuel Arnold, one of our principal townsmen and proprietor of the Depot Flouring Mills, being a first cousin of Eliza Garfield. The old lady, in years past, has made a number of visits to her relatives living here. James has also visited the family of Samuel Arnold, but not since the latter removed to this place.

PANAMA, Sept. 24.--The German ship Hugo was destroyed by fire in the South Pacific, latitude 42 south, longitude 87 west, on Aug. 9. The longboat, with the Captain, the carpenter, and seven men, arrived at Chiloe, Chili, having made 800 miles in nine days.

At Pembroke College, Cambridge, has been brought to light the solid silver mitre and crozier which belonged to Bishop Wren, the uncle of Sir Christopher Wren, the architect of St. Paul's. Bishop Wren was successively Bishop of Here ford, of Norwich, and of Ely.

LONDON, Sept. 16.--The French are apparently awakening to the fact that the English Government is in earnest in refusing to renew the commercial treaty on French terms. The Gladstone Cabinet is fully alive to the public sentiment of England in regard to the grasping character of the French proposals.

The Committee of One Hundred, through whose labors the "New-York County Democracy" was organized and placed in its present position, met for the last time last evening in their rooms in West Twenty-fourth-street. Charles Young, trading under the style of John Young Son, dealer in upper leathers, at No. 75 Gold-street, has failed, and has offered to compromise at 25 cents on the dollar, which has been accepted by the principal creditors. The failure is attributed to losses in business, shrinkage in values, and too much incumbered real estate.

Carleton, Chairman of the Port Huron Committee, in response to a telegraphic inquiry from Treasurer Dowd, reports that in that city on Saturday the funds on hand amounted to $98,729.66.

A billiard tournament was begun yesterday in the Brunswick Billiard Hall, No. 1,292 Broadway. It is held as a preliminary to a general tournament to be opened on Nov. 14 in Tammany Hall, and is designed to establish the game of cushion caroms in public favor.

BOSTON, Oct. 3.--Signor Ernesto Rossi, the Italian tragedian, made his first appearance in America at the Globe Theatre to-night, in the presence of a large and brilliant audience. He played King Lear, speaking the lines in Italian, the company using the Shakesperean text.

SING SING, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The total earnings at Sing Sing Prison for the fiscal year ending Sept. 31, 1881, are $229,254 14; total expenditures, $187,127.20, leaving a net profit for the year of $42,126.94.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The Conkling wing of the Republican Party to-day nominated P.W. Cullinan for member of Assembly. The anti-machine convention to nominate a candidate is called to meet on Monday, Oct. 10.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Oct. 3.--The hearing in the elevated railroad case, which was set down at Judge Westbrook's Supreme Court. Chambers, here to-day, was postponed for a few days in order that the Manhattan Receivers might have more time for preparation.

ALBANY, Oct. 3.--The Palestine Encampment of Odd-fellows, of Lynn, Mass., arrived here to-day, and was received by a committee of Albany Odd-fellows. To-morrow they will visit points of interest, and next day start for New-York by the day boat.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9.--Thousands of persons visited Lakerview Cemetery to-day. The park wherein the body of the late President lay in state is thronged with visitors night and day. All the railways centring here run special trains daily to accommodate the multitude.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 9.--The steamer S.C. Walker, of Philadelphia, Captain Mulford, loaded with coal and bound from this port to Wilmington. The cargo, which was valued at $450, was insured.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 9.--Jacob Hochberg employed at the Hazard Wire-robe Works, was dangerously injured last night. He was washing wire in an immense tub of hot water and vitriol, when, making a misstep, he fell forward and plunged headlong into the tub. A number of men ran to his assistance, and he was drawn from the tub in great agony. He was so horribly burned that his death is hourly expected.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 10.--In all directions the Republicans seem to be anticipating a certain victory, so far as the State ticket goes, and with a strong hope also of carrying the Legislature. The much-talked of apathy among the Republicans is matched with equal dullness on the Democratic side.

Mr. C.M. Stokes, chief clerk of the road, had a narrow escape from death. He was at dinner at his home, in Thirty-third-street, within a few blocks of the stable, when a messenger informed him of the fire's outbreak. He rushed to the scene to find the Lexington-avenue and Thirty-third-street sides of the stable ...

BOSTON, Oct. 10.--The celebration of the one thousandth performance of Hazel Kirke at the Park Theatre to-night was magnificent in all its details. So great was the crowd that the doors were positively closed to all comers at 8 o'clock. The floral decorations in the entrance and elsewhere excelled all similar demonstrations known in Boston.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Oct. 10.--The Catholic Total Abstinence Union of the Diocese of Scranton, numbering between 3,000 and 4,000 members, met in this city to-day in honor of the birth of Father Mathew. High mass was celebrated at the cathedral at 9 o'clock, after which the union participated in a street parade, the largest ever seen here.
The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club will be brought to a close to-day with an interesting programme, and the entries are numerous enough to make a very fine day's sport.
This is the first day of registration in this City. Voters who take an interest in good government should not fail to register to-day.

The trial of the contest of the will of the late Alonzo C. Yates, the Syracuse millionaire, who procured a divorce from his first wife to marry his former cook, was again before Surrogate Calvin yesterday. Mrs. Anna C. Yates, the first wife, who, with her children, is contesting the ...
LONDON, Oct. 10.--Mr. Cadogan has been appointed attach of the British Legation at Washington.
LONDON, Oct. 10.--Mr. Cadogan has been appointed attach of the British Legation at Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10.--Secretary Windom has decided to be a candidate for the United States Senate. Mr. Edgerton, who was appointed by the Governor of Minnesota to succeed Mr. Windom, does not desire to press his claim on the Legislature in view of the melancholy circumstances that make ...

The official returns of the votes cast in the November election of 1879 show conclusively that a bargain existed between the Tammany Boss and Mr. George Bliss. Kelly agreed to deliver votes for Messrs. Ward and Wadsworth, the Republican candidates for Attorney-General and Controller, and in return Mr. Bliss was to support Kelly's nominee, Gumbleton.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 11.--The total vote of Iowa last year was 321,000. Partial reports from nine counties indicate that there will be a falling off this year of probably 60,000.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11.--The French visitors, who are now the guests of this city, passed a quiet forenoon at the Mount Vernon Hotel, resting after their rapid visit to Niagara Falls and thence to Baltimore. About noon they were waited on by the joint reception committee and were taken in carriages for a drive through the city.
LONDON, Oct. 11.--A Cario dispatch says: "The Turkish delegates state that they will make their report to the Sultan and await his reply."

Bunnell, who had testified that he was at Savin Rock the Friday night before the Saturday that Jennie Cramer's body was found; that he had known her about three years, and knew James Malley ...

The inadequacy of the water supply at the fire was the subject of indignant comment yesterday. Deputy Public Works Commissioner Frederick H. Hamlin, when spoken to by a TIMES reporter on the subject, said that "immediately upon receiving telegraphic instructions from Fire Department Head-quarters one of the watchmen who ...
ALGIERS, Oct. 11.--Gen. Saussier has embarked for Tunis to assume command of the operations there.

The steam-ship Bermuda, Capt. Faircloth, which arrived from Arroyo and several other ports of the West Indies yesterday, brought the crew of the British brig I'Edouard, which was lost during a huricane on Aug. 25. The I'Edouard sailed from St. John, Newfoundland, for Ponce with a cargo of fish last June. After landing her freight at the latter port she proceeded to Humaco, Porto Rico, in ballast.

When the United States Supreme Court convened on Monday for its regular annual session there was a bare quorum of six Justices present. Mr. Justice FIELD is absent in Europe, and it has been intimated that he does not expect to take his place on the bench for some time to come.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11.--Messrs. Miller and Lapham, of New-York, and Aldrich, of Rhode Island, were duly admitted to seats in the Senate to-day, no objection being made to their taking the oath. Mr. McPherson presented a paper signed by certain Democratic ...

While in London, England, in 1871, Mr. William R. Hynes, a well-known and wealthy citizen of this City, met a woman named Mrs. Mary E. Saunders, and married her in the presence of witnesses by putting a ring upon one of her fingers and telling her he would hold her as his wife so long as she acted honestly toward him.

The neighborhood of the great fire of Monday night the block bounded by Lexington and Fourth avenues and Thirty-second and Thirty-third streets, was crowded with men, women, and chilaren all day yesterday, and at times the Police found it almost impossible to keep the throng without the circle of the fire lines so as to enable the firemen to work to advantage.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--The wholesale provision firm of Washington Butcher's Sons, the largest house in the city, whose warehouse is in Front-street, below Race-street, suspended this afternoon, with liabilities ranging from $1,000,000 to $3,000,000. The former estimate of the losses is given by one of the members of the house.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11--9 P.M.--Reports received from various cities in Ohio indicate that the election to-day has been an unusually quiet one. Up to 9 o'clock to-night only 15 returns have been received, owing, no doubt, to the liberal scratching on both sides.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 10.--Upon the eve of the assembling of the extra session of the Legislature, called by Gov. Pillsbury to take final action for the settlement of the old bonded debt, it cannot be said that the prospect for the redemption of Minnesota from the dishonor of 20 years is very bright.

The new Republican State Committee created by the recent convention in this City met yesterday to organize at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. There were 27 of the 33 members present, 5 were represented by proxies and 1, Capt. M. Cregan, of this City, was absent.

LONDON, Oct. 11.--This was the second day of the Newmarket second October meeting. The race for the Cesarewitch Stakes, distance 2 miles, 2 furlongs, and 28 yards, was won by Mr. J.R. Keene's 3-year-old b.c. Foxhall. Lord Bradford's 5-year-old br. h. Chippendale secured the second place, and the ...

The testimony given yesterday at the trial of Martin Kenkowski for the murder of Mina Muller in the woods at Guttenberg was rather more interesting than it had been for some days before. Mrs. Francis Clifford, to whose house on Charlesstreet, the State claims, Kenkowski moved after the murder, was called to the stand, but she was unable to identify the prisoner as having been among her boarders.

The work of estimating the losses by the great fire of Monday night, which destroyed the Fourth-avenue car stables and the greater part of Morrell's storage warehouse, was carried on assiduously all day yesterday and well into the night. Mr. Morrell said the entire damage to the warehouse and its contents would be from $1,000,000 to $1,500,000.
LISBON, Oct. 11.--The Portuguese Court goes into four days' mourning for the late President Garfield.

The steam-ship Harald, from Copenhagen, landed 318 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday. THE TIMES has received $5 from William Bedell for the Garfield fund, and $1 from H. and E. N. for a like purpose.

The Controller of the Currency has made up with commendable promptness his resume of the reports of the national banks of this City, presented to him on the first of the month. It will be found in tabular form in our columns this morning.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11, 1881. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $272,000. The receipts from internal revenue to-day were $428,509,69, and from Customs $584,878,35.

The gold and silver mines of the United States form one of the most important factors in the world's trade, as they now produce about as much as the mines of the rest of the world combined. The production of gold in the United States since 1848 has been nearly one billion five hundred and fifty millions of dollars, and of silver five hundred millions of dollars.

A new treatise by the distinguished author of "The Law of Freedom and Bondage in the United States"--a work which, though published in the year 1858, has ever since, and through all the changes of the long interval, remained the undisputed standard on its subject, no need existing to supersede it--cannot fail to be welcomed by all students of constitutional law.

The Republican Convention made one grave error. It failed to take any action for the purification and improvement of our defective caucus system. That the plan of choosing delegates and making nominations now in vogue is imperfect and entirely inadequate to secure the fullest expression of the wishes of the people under ordinary circumstances was never more apparent than it has been this Fall.

The Citizens' Committee of Twenty-one, whose efforts last Spring to procure a reform in street-cleaning methods in this City are so well remembered, held an important meeting yesterday at No. 79 Fourth-avenue to talk over the subject of street-cleaning, present and future.

ALBANY, Oct. 11.--Tammany's good humor, maintained yesterday afternoon with a wonderful pretense of indifference as to the result of the meeting of the State Committee to be held at night, departed with the coming of the small hours to-day, as soon as the vote had been taken by which Kelly was again thrust out into the cold and held up to the ridicule and scorn of the political world.

At the meeting or the Board of Health yesterday, the rules and regulations for the registration of plumbers, as revised in accordance with Chapter 450 of the Laws of 1881, were adopted. These rules require, at the outset, that every plumber engaged in business in the City of NewYork shall appear in person at the Health Department, No. 301 Mott-street, and register his name and address.

Downing, District Attorney of Queens County, and for several ...

HARTFORD, Oct. 11.--Lieut.-Col. Daniel C. Rodman, formerly of the Seventh Connecticut Volunteers, and more recently Pension Agent for Connecticut, died on Sunday night at Groton after a long and painful struggle with consumption, the result of the wounds and exposure of the war. Col. Rodman was a rough diamond, liable if ...
AUBURN, N.Y., Oct. 11.--Joe Coburn, the former pugilist, was to-day transferred to Sing Sing Prison by order of Superintendent Pilsbury.

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club was brought to a close yesterday with some excellent racing, which was witnessed by a large and enthusiastic assemblage. There were, as usual, six races on the programme, and the honors were equally divided, as three of the favorites reached the winning-post first.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 11.--A resolution introduced in the Senate of Minnesota to-day by Gen. John B. ALBANY, Oct. 11.--In the Court of Appeals to-day, the following decisions were handed down: Beyer vs. The People; Mullay vs. The People; Shipply vs. The People; Read vs. The People--Judgment affirmed. Perry vs. The People; Rodgers vs. The People--Judgment and venira de novo ordered.

DUBLIN, Sept. 17.--This has been an exciting week. Two important events have taken place, the meeting of the national convention for the consideration of the Land act and the gathering at the Mansion House for the purposed of furthering arrangements for the proposed Irish industrial exhibition of next year.

Thrift is an excellent quality, and it is, perhaps, the predominating quality of the Connecticut man. The Scotchman is proverbially careful of his pennies to the end that his pounds may quietly develop themselves therefrom, but it is doubtful if he is as thoroughly familiar with the science of economy as is the thrifty Connecticut person.

The underwriters met yesterday afternoon to consider the insurance and the losses by the fire. On the stables and contents belonging to the Harlem Railroad Company, damaged, as stated, to the amount of $350,000, there is $150,000 of insurance divided among the following 29 companies:

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 10.--The campaign in Pennsylvania up to this time has been one thoroughly unique. Its like never was witnessed in this State. There is no excitement, but a lively interest. There is great uncertainty as to the result, but thousands of party men--in both parties--are thoroughly indifferent concerning it.

The Twenty-third Assembly District Republican Association met last night at its head-quarters, One Hundred and Thirtieth-street and Thirdavenue, and was engineered, as usual, by Mr. Frank Raymond, the "boss" of the district. Mr. Frank Raymond offered resolutions eulogizing Gen. Garfield.

The expectation of politicians that the meeting of the Bar Association last evening would be largely attended, and that an animated discussion would take place at it, was not realized. Only about one-seventh of the members of the association were present, and the proceedings were very tame.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 11.--At the Republican Congressional Convention held at Lowville, to-day, Charles R. Skinner was unanimously nominated for Congress.

The assembling of the Democratic State Convention in Albany has been the occasion for bringing prominently before the people an eminent statesman from Chemung County. Heretofore Chemung has been chiefly honorable in the political annals of the State as the home of ex-Gov. ROBINSON.
Mr. Charles Cheshire has been elected Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Republican General Committee and Mr. William H. Leavcraft has been elected Chairman of the Campaign Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11.--Though Saturday was the last day for registering Reading Railroad stock to be voted on at the next election there is almost as much uncertainty about the result now as there was a month ago, and this notwithstanding that there is more interest felt in the matter here than in any other subject.

Ten years have passed away since the great Chicago fire. It was on the 8th of October, 1871, at about 9 o'clock in the evening, that the fire bells rung forth an unwelcome alarm of fire--doubly unwelcome to the Fire Department because it had just returned home from an extensive conflagration which had broken out Saturday night, the 7th of October, and which had left the men sleepless and exhausted.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11.--What was once known as the Hartford, Providence and Fishkill Railroad, but is now the New-York and NewEngland Railroad, it is announced, will be complated, and trains will be running through from Boston by the route to the Hudson River, a distance of 228 miles, by Nov. 1. It is said that the steamer Maryland, now plying between Jersey City and Harlem as a transportation boat.
Somebody estimates that the recent heavy frost did $1,000,000 worth of damage in the territort within 10 miles of Boston.

A fashionable wedding took place last evening at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth-avenue and Forty-fifth-street, the high contracting parties being Miss C. Matilda Lowerre, only daughter of Mr. Seaman Lowerre, and Mr. Lewis Nelson Morris, son of Col. Thomas F. Morris, of Brooklyn.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Oct. 12.--On Saturday evening, last, in a speech at Titusville, Charles S. Wolfe, the Independent candidate for State Treasurer, made sweeping charges against Gov. Hoyt, and attacked the honesty of the management of the State Treasury.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The following general order has been issued from the office of the adjutant-General:

CHICAGO, Oct. 12.--The nefarious business of grain gambling is threatened with annihilation here in its own particular abode. The statutes of the State provide severe penalties for the crime of "cornering" and forestalling the grain market, but hitherto the law has been permitted to lie as a dead letter.

TUNIS, Oct. 12.--M. Roustan, the French Minister, has addressed a circular to the representatives of the powers informing them of the occupation of Tunis by virtue of an understanding with the Bey, the occupation to be purely military and the Administration to continue as heretofore.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 12.--The Republicans elect their entire county ticket. The city of Des Moines gives all the Republican candidates a majority.

The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Western Union. Telegraph Company was held yesterday. Among the prominent gentlemen present were President Norvin Green, General Manager Thomas T. Eckert, Vice-President John Van Horne, Vice-President Augustus Schell, Vice-President Harrison Durkee, Rnssell Sage, Sidney Dillon, Cyrus W. Field, and James H. Banker.

Mr. Cyrus W. Field burried down Broadway through the rain and slush yesterday afternoon and climbed up the steps leading to No. 80 Broadway. Upon the second floor is the down-town private office of Mr. Jay Gould, and up to the second floor and into that private office went Mr. Field.

Two men called at the house of John C. Van Horne, a well-known and wealthy resident of Jersey City, on Saturday afternoon last, and inquired for Mr. Van Horne, saying to the servant that they wished to see him on private business.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--Congressman Joseph Jorgensen, of Virginia, one of the straightout Republicans who has, up to the present time, taken no active part in the political campaign in his State, has at last given in his adherence to the Liberal Reform movement, and will labor hereafter to secure the success of ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12.--The Republican Senators met in caucus to-day and, after considerable discussion, decided to present the name of Senator David Davis, of Illinois, for President pro tem. No time was fixed for introducing the necessary resolution, but it is probable that the matter will be pressed tomorrow or Friday.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., Oct. 12.--The Hon. James W. Wadsworth was to-day nominated for representative in Congress, to succeed Senator Lapham, on the first formal ballot, by a vote of 19 to 14. The convention was animated by good feeling throughout and promises a rousing majority for the Republican ticket in this Congressional district.

There is still considerable fire in the ruins of the Fourth-avenue stables and the Morrell warehouse, although throughout the day yesterday and all last night steamers were pouring water on the smoldering ruins.

A good deal of attention has been paid by the press to the recent interview between the Kings of Spain and Portugal, which took place at one of those improbable Spanish towns with names far too long ever to be written or pronounced, except by people of leisure.

LONDON, Oct. 12.--The race for the Middle Park Plate for 2-year olds at the Newmarket second October meeting to-day was won by Lord Rosebery's br. f. Kermesse. Mr. P. Lorillard's br. c. Gerald secured the socond place, and Mr. W.S. Crawfurd's ch. f. St. Marguerite came in third.
The trial of the suit of Miss Genevieve Ward, the actress, against Messrs. Theodore Moss and Lester Wallack, is progressing before ChiefJustice Sedgwick in the Superior Court, Special Term.

ALTANTA, Ga., Oct. 8.--In its present incomplete state Atlanta's cotton fair is a far less interesting study than the new spirit in the South of which it is an outcome. Whether as a starting point, or a first milestone, an impulse or the record of progress already made, the exposition now taking shape in Oglethorpe ...
YORKTOWN, Oct. 12.--Everything is behindhand for the opening ceremonies of Thursday, but as they are not the important ones, little annoyance is expressed.
The San Francisco Call makes the absurd estimate that the Chinese laborers in California send home $15,000,000 every year.
The special train chartered by the Tammany delegation reached the Grand Central Depot at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon direct from the Democratic State Convention at Albany.

TROY, N.Y., Oct. 12.--Edward Earl, the Hamilton County wife-murderer, will be hanged on Friday, on the gallows built in 1871 for the hanging of Charles Eacker, at Fonda, and since used to put to death a dozen murderers. The rope is the one which killed Greenfield, the Oswego murderer, a few weeks ago.

The New-York committee having in charge the work of providing relief for the suffering people of Michigan forwarded $35,000 yesterday to the State commission recently appointed by Gov. Jerome to superintend disbursements in that State.
WILLIAM PURCELL, the candidate for Secretary of State, was born in Franklin County, in this State, in 1836. He is a nephew of Archbishop Purcell, of Cincinnati.

How much less the loss by the great fire of Monday night would have been if the engines had not been embarrassed by an insufficient supply of water it is impossible to estimate, but the peril involved in a constant liability to such embarrassment is sufficiently manifest.
ALEXANDRIA, Oct. 12.--Thirteen fatal cases of cholera occurred at Mecca between the 5th and 30th of September.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 12.--The victory gained by the Republicans yesterday against the combined opposition of the Democrats, the Prohibitionists, and the Greenbackers is more complete in every respect than was anticipated by the most enthusiastic Republicans.

The Fall opening at Lord Taylor's Grandstreet store attracted a large number of patrons on Tuesday and yesterday. A large portion of the trade of this store comes from up town and across from Brooklyn by way of the ferry.

DUBLIN, Oct. 12.--At the Land League meeting yesterday, Mr. Dillon, after denouncing the Land act, and stigmatizing Mr. Gladstone as a dishonest politician, said he repented of his intention not to participate actively in Land act affairs until the tenants had an opportunity of using the measure.
The engagement of Mr. and Mrs. McKee Rankin at the Fourteenth-Street Theatre will end on Saturday night. "The Strategists" will be revived at this house on next Monday night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 12, 1881. The national bank notes received for re- demption to-day amounted to $153,000.
Lower and heavy markets, with active speculation, marked the day at the Produce Exchange yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 12.--At the regular monthly meeting of the Board of Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company to-day the Committee of Finance submitted its report of the earning and expenses of the road for the fiscal half year ending ...
ALBANY, Oct. 12.--The Democratic convention is over, and the throng of delegates and hangers-on who have crowded the streets and hotels for three days have gone home.

A long train of devoted friends and relatives wound up on Tuesday the beautiful hills which line the Farmington River near Tariffville, Conn., to pay their last respects to this loyal friend and devoted helper of the poor.

The first tour of the season to discover and report truant school-boys was made yesterday by the truancy agents. The ground gone over was the first district of the First Ward, embracing all that territory which lies below Maiden-lane and Liberty-street from river to river.

It is but a few days since one of Herr Moser's new comedies was acted here for the first time on the stage of the Germania Theatre; another new comedy by an equally well-known and popular playwright, Herr Julius Rosen, was brought out on the same stage last night, also for the first time.

The first important State elections since the Presidential contest of last year occurred in Ohio and Iowa on Tuesday last, and the result furnishes no evidence of a reaction of public sentiment against the Republican Party.
The Democratic convention was presided over yesterday by Mr. ERASTUS BROOKS, an old-time Democrat in point of age, but, as his remarks showed but too plainly, not an old-time Democrat in his views.

The Tammany Committee on Organization held a secret session last evening, with John Kelly in the chair. The attendance was unusually large. It was said that seldom in the history of the organization had so many members of the committee gathered together, and that the hopes expressed for the success of the Tammany cause were never more earnest.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 13.--Star chamber courts don't work in Ohio. It was a desperate move of Gould's to compel the courts to aid him in securing the Ohio and Mississippi ...

ALBANY, Oct. 13.--With great prompt ness the Democratic State Committee appointed in the cenvention yesterday opened its head-quarters here to-day, in State-street, and Mr. Manning, the Chairman, will run the campaign within a block of his place of business. For several successive years the State Committee has had its head-quarters in New-York.

PARIS, Oct. 13.--It is semi-officially announced that Great Britain and France have addressed identical instructions to their representatives at Cairo and Constantinople upon the Egyptian question.

Wall-street was convinced yesterday that the close of the elevated railroad war is at hand. Manhattan opened at 33 , jumped to 40, and closed at 45. DUBLIN, Oct. 13.--Mr. Parnell was arrested to-day at Morrison's Hotel, where he was stopping previous to starting for the Kildare convention at Naas. Detective Mallon called at the hotel at 9 o'clock this morning and sent word to the Land League leader, who was still in bed, that he would like to see him.

BOSTON, Oct. 13.--After several months' inquiry, the Committee of Twenty-eight, appointed to consider the feasiblity of holding a World's Fair in Boston, met to-day to hear the final report on the subject. It reports that while the general opinion in New-England seems to favor the holding of the fair, in Boston it was impossible to ascertain ...

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 13.--Friends of George W. Hunt, the Paying Teller of the Importers and Traders' Bank, of New-York, who is charged with embezzling $16,000 of the bank's funds, have recently visited him, and he has made a statement to them which throws some light upon the case.

Formad, involving the important discovery that this fatal and insidious disease is propagated by a microscopic plant or fungi, ...

NEWTON, N.Y., Oct. 13.--The Lehigh and Hudson Railroad, which is designed to connect the Pennsylvania Railroad and the coal roads crossing the Delaware with the New-England Road at Fishkill, on the Hudson, River, is pushing along rapidly. The track is already laid six miles from Belvidere, and will be completed to Andover by Dec. 1.

Woman suffragists claim that notable progress has been made during 1881, and support the assertion by interesting facts. During the year Maine gave women a right to serve on school committees, and enacted that married women may sell and convey real and personal estate, but refused the ballot.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 13.--A special dispatch from Hannibal, Mo., says: "While the famlly of Hiram Westfall were seated at breakfast yesterday morning they were suddenly attacked with sickness and commenced vomiting. The persons at the table were Mr. Westfall, his wife, a young lady, and a hired man.

There is considerable discussion and some difference of opinion among the members of the Produce Exchange relative to the plan that shall be finally adopted for the new Exchange building to be erected by that body, and a meeting of the Board of Managers has been called to consider the subject, which will be brought up in the from of a report rendered by the Building Committee.

The election of Mr. DAVID DAVIS, of Illinois, to replace Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, as temporary President of the Senate, will generally be accepted by the Republican Party as a sensible escape from what bade fair to become an embarrassing situation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13, 1881. The national bank notes received for re demption to-day amounted to $139,000.

YORKTOWN, Va., Oct. 13.--The affairs of the centennial celebration to-day are even less prosperous than yesterday. It is now certain that there will be no opening until Saturday, when the speeches by Prof. Charlier and Mr. Coudert, of New-York, are expected. The Hon. Carl Schurz is not likely to come, owing to pressure of other engagements.

The loss of the steam-ship Teuton has led to the discovery of a hitherto unsuspected danger attending the modern method of ship-building. The Teuton was an iron steam-ship, fitted with water-tight bulkheads.

MONTREAL, Oct. 13.--Advices from the scene of the disaster to the steam-ship Corean report her in a very dangerous position. VIENNA, Oct. 18.--Preparations are making at Moscow for the coronation of Alexander III.

PROVIDENCE, R.I. Oct. 18.--At Woonsocket this morning the Coroner's jury rendered the vardict that Josephine Hinton, a servant, 18 years old, came to her death Oct. 3 from taking poison, and that Alfred Thomas was accessory to her death and morally responsible. Thomas is in custody.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 18.--To-day was the opening of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club, at Pimlico. The attendance was larger than ever known on an opening day, and the races were all excellent. There were five contests, though the fields were not large.

John McKeon, the nominee for District-Attorney, has been an ardent Democrat always, and so long ago as 1835 was elected to Congress from this City. He was born in this City 77 years ago, and has never resided elsewhere.

By an almost unanimous vote the Brooklyn Young Republican Club last evening indorsed the claims of Mr. Ripley Ropes to the Mayoralty of Brooklyn. The meeting, which was held in Music Hall, at Flatbush-avenue and Fultonstreet, was attended by between 500 and 600 members, and was presided over by the President of the club, Mr. Horace E. Deming.

A State Temperance Convention is to be held in Lexington, Ky., to-day and to-morrow. A small boy in Boston was instantly killed on Tuesday evening by a top pistol in the hands of his 19-year-old brother.

Parties in the United States Senate have not been so evenly divided as now since the foundation of the Government. In 1846, when there were several vacancies, and pending the elections to fill these, the Whigs in the Senate numbered 24 and the Democrats 26.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--A document which is now in the hands of the officers of the Post Office Department throws considerable light on the character of the Hon. James N. Tyner, and shows that he had, at one time, a lively appreciation of the iniquities of the "star" service.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 19.--It was rumored here this evening that the steamer Charleston had been lost at sea. Nothing is known here to confirm the rumor. The boat is an old one, and was taken off the Charleston and New-York route several years ago.

The second of the series of three races between first class sloops of the New-York Yacht Club took place yesterday, having been postponed from Friday of last week in consequence of the accidents to the Gracie and Pocahontas in the race of last Thursday.

The parlors of No. 11 East Seventeenthstreet, which have been transformed into a bookstore by the publishing house of Houghton, Mifflin Co., were formally opened to the public yesterday, and from noon until 4 o'clock they were thronged with distinguished representatives of the literary and legal professions and with members of numerous publishing firms of this and other cities.

There has been a very general discussion throughout the West of the general subject of gambling in grain brought up by the charge of Judge JAMESON, of Chicago, to the Grand Jury of Cook County, in which he called their attention to an Illinois statute making such gambling an offense punishable by fine and imprisonment.

The New-York Board of Trade and Transportation met yesterday afternoon, President Ambrose Snow in the chair. Among the members present were F.B. Thurber, A.B. Miller, Josiah J. White, Ferdinand P. Earle, A.M. Coffin, A.S. Barnes, Thomas P. Ball, Edmund P. Martin, and Charles Partridge.

Mr. Charles Van Benthuysen, of Albany, the well-known head of the house of Charles Van Benthuysen Son, died, died yesterday morning in the St. James Hotel, in this City, after an illness of but a few hours.

RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 16.--The railroad fight in this State has brought along the concomitants of crimination, recrimination, and political scandal. In a contest like this it seems to be in order to impeach motives and to tell all you know on your adversary. This is now being done as if by contract.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19.--The second day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club equaled yesterday. The weather was fine, the attendance large, and the track in splendid condition. There were five races, all of which excited great interest.

DUBLIN, Oct. 19.--At the Land League meeting, yesterday, the Rev. Mr. Cantwell, who presided, announced that, although the weekly meetings would be discontinued, the business of the League would, as far as possible, continue to be transacted at its rooms in Dublin. He urgently advised the people to avoid collision with armed forces.

NEWPORT, R.I., Oct. 19.--The Channing Memorial Church dedication took place here today. Large delegations were present from NewYork, Boston, and Providence, and the church was crowded long before the opening of the services, which occurred at 11 o'clock, opening with the anthem "Venite," by Millard.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19.--The recent discovery of petroleum in Northern Germany promises important results, and the indications are, according to late advices received at the State Department, that the discovery will seriously interfere with our export of petroleum to Europe.
STAUNTON, Va., Oct. 19.--William Bolen, of Rockbridge, was shot and killed yesterday by George Smith. The difficulty grew out of an old grudge.

Early in May last Mayor Grace instructed Messrs. Shearman and Barrow, the Commissioners of Accounts, to make an investigation of the business and accounts of the Department of Docks and report upon any arrearages or irregularities which might be discovered. The report of this investigation was sent to the Mayor yesterday.

In the commemoration of the surrender of Lord CORNWALLIS at Yorktown there has been rather scanty recognition of the services to this country which were performed by the English on that occasion and during the struggle of which it was the virtual termination.

PARIS, Oct. 3.--A French newspaper has a report that the men who stole the body of Mr. A.T. Stewart have agreed to give it up for a consideration. The family of the late M.B., a wealthy Parisian tradesman, recently deceased, make known that they are prepared to pay handsomely for any information concerning his remains.

BOSTON, Oct. 19.--The fifth annual meeting of the American Humane Association commenced here to-day, Mr. E.L. Brown, of Chicago, presiding. He said the association should have its agents in every city and town, stating that the extension of its working force would cost nor more than $18,000 or $20,000.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Oct. 20.--The Republican Senatorial Convention for the Thirteenth District was held here to-day. Sol Dickey, of Newburg, was Chairman. Senator Madden was renominated by acclamation. When brought before the convention Mr. Madden positively declined to be a candidate.

Currency has recently been given to rumors predicting the revisal of the World's Fair project. The story was told again yesterday. BALTIMORE, Oct. 20.--The third day of the Fall meeting of the Maryland Jockey Club was quite equal to either of the preceding days. There were five races, all well contested. Parole captured the first and third. Brambaletta the second, Greenland the fourth, and Ingomar the fifth.

Emanuel Marks, No. 454 in the Rogues' Gallery, was arrested yesterday in a Sixth-avenue hotel. Marks is 42 years old, and an accomplished criminal. He began his nefarious career as a "confidence" operator, and became a bank "sneak." He left New-York 10 years ago because he was too well known to the Police, and made Chicago his head-quarters. From there he and his confederates went to various Western cities and swindled greenhorns.

The alterative mineral waters, which constitute our third class, are of great importance. They possess special alterative properties which distinguish them from other water in their effects upon the system. All medicinal waters are less or more alternative in their action. The cathartic and diuretic waters change the action of the system to some extent, but their alterative action is secondary to and in consequence of their primary action.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29.--M.H. McGuire, tobacconist, was closen out in business by his New-York and Chicago creditors to-day. INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29.--The city and State are in trouble over the composition of their Boards of Health. INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 29.--Among the names mentioned for political appointments is that of the Hon. Jesse J. Brown, of New-Albany. Mr. Brown is one of our wealthiest and most prominent Republicans. He was the trusted friend and adviser of Senator Morton, and during the Presidency of Gen. Grant declined the position of Controller of the Currency and of Treasurer of the United States. It is not probable he would accept any office now.

CINCINNATE, Oct. 29.--For two days the whisky market has been much disturbed, with a decided downward tendency. BORDENTOWN, N.J., Nov. 1.--The farmers of Burlington and surrounding counties are rejoicing over the abatement of the drought. It has been raining off and on for the last three days. Wells and streams which have been dry for months have been replenished. In several eases farmers have had to drive their stock miles to water them.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 2.--Bears seem to be growing numerous in the back part of this and Greene Counties, and many have been seen during the past Summer and Fall. Hunters are now in active preparation for the trapping season, which covers the next two months.

Two of the five expeditions among which the Government divided its Arctic search energies for the year 1881 have now substantially completed their work. The revenue cutter Corwin is safely back at San Francisco, and now the Alliance is also in home waters.

There was a full attendance at the meeting of the Board of Education yesterday, President Stephen A. Walker in the chair. City Superintendent John Jasper reported that the total number of cases investigated by the Agents of Truancy in October was 982.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 2.--An excursion party, consisting of the President and Directors and other officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, a number of business men and capitalists of the city, and representatives of the press, left here this morning on a special train for Johnstown, Penn., to be present at the formal opening of the Somerset and Cambria Railroad on Thursday.
Mails out of New-York for the West will be greatly facilitated by important arrangements completed by Postmaster-General James, which were reported to Postmaster Pearson, of this City, yesterday.

LIMERICK, Nov. 2.--Two thousand tenant farmers in the County of Limerick have resolved to apply to the Land Commission to fix judicial rent or set aside unjust leases.

Mr. John Hutchinson, of the firm of Hutchinson Hall, dry goods dealers at Branford, Conn., called on Inspector Byrnes, at the Central Office, yesterday, and reported the particulars of a masked burglary perpetrated at his store on the morning of the 1st inst.

BOSTON, Nov. 2.--At 10 o'clock to-day the French visitors arrived here as the special guests of the city. They were received at Mansfield by a committee representing this city. Along the line of the railroad large crowds were in waiting to get a glimpse of the visitors, who were especially in charge of S.A. Brown, Chief Clerk of the Department of State, Washington.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 2.--Local political matters are being agitated now with a vigor which it was impossible to arouse earlier in the campaign. It was discovered yesterday that a great number of errors had been made in printing the Assessors' lists of voters.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2.--Information has been received of the first political murder of the recent campaign in Mississippi, which occurred in Sharkey County on Friday night, Oct 28. A Sharkey County Fusion meeting was held on the Phelps plantation, on Deer Creek.

The Hon, Hannibal Hamlin, the new Minis-- ter to Spain, said at the dinner given him by Boston friends on Tuesday evening last: "Unsolicited, the President, who is taken from us by the hand of an assassin, conferred upon me the appointment of Minister to Spain.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 2.--In the session of the American Missionary Society to-day, the Committee on the Revision of the Constitution made ite report. The principal changes recommended are to omit the evangelical clause from the requirement for membership and to do away with the annual membership fee.

Tammanyites expressed dissatisfaction yesterday when it became noised among them that John McKeon, the candidate of the united Democracy for District Attorney, has not paid any assessment to the organization, and that in a general way he displays an evident desire not to seek the society of its members.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 2.--This afternoon W. H. Gurney, the well-known lawyer, deliberately committed suicide by lowering himself into Niagara River. For some time he has been in an unsound state of mind.
The Rev. Nathaniel Hicks Van Arsdale, late of Batavia. Ill., is to be installed Pastor of the Broadway Reformed Church, Paterson, to-night.

The first rehearsal of the twenty-fourth season was given at the Academy of Music, in Montague-street, yesterday afternoon, under the direction of Mr. Theodore Thomas. The Board of Bishops of the Methodist Episcopal Church, who have been holding their annual meeting in the Methodist Book Concern building at Broadway and Eleventh-street, finished their work and adjourned yesterday.

The cry of a potato famine in this country has occasioned the importation of tons of the genuine Irish potato to this port, and many barrels of them were yesterday displayed at the stores of Heard Co., in Dey-street, near the North River.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2.--Paymaster-General N.W. Brown has submitted his annual report to the Secretary of War. During the fiscal year ended June 30, the receipts were $15,630,967 80. all of which amount was accounted for.

An informal meeting of holders of certain North Carolina bonds to discuss the propriety of resorting to legal measures to compel that State to recognize her own indebtedness was held in the Astor House yesterday afternoon.

LONDON, Nov. 3.--Confederate dollar bonds declined to 1 2s. 6d. per 100. Suicides in France during the past 30 years have incresed with alarming rapidly. The percentage is 78. The Governing Committee of the Stock Exchange held a long session on Wednesday afternoon, and it was dark before an adjournment was reached. Chief among the matters considered was a charga of "commission splitting" preferred against Seba M. Bogart, broker, of No. 15 Wallstreet.

Miss Carrie E.Mason, a young and accomplished soprano, made her first appearance in concert at Chickering Hall last evening. This young lady evidently has a host of friends, for the house was remarkably well filled, notwithstanding the inelement weather and the numerous attractions at every other place of amusement.

WASHINGTON, Del., Nov. 3.--The trial of William Arrants for the murder of Nicholas Volcker at guilty. The jury deliberated only 20 dict of not guilty. The jury deliberated only 20 minutes. No evidence but that of a purely circumstantial nature was brought out at the trial.

CINCINNATI, Nov.3.--A meeting for the consideration of the city's water supply was held today at the Board of Trade Rooms. It was made up of representatives duly appointed of the Chamber of Commerce, the Boards of Trade and Transportation and the Tax-payers' League.

LONDON, Nov. 3.--The Norwegian bark Dagmar, Capt. Christensen, from Sthediac, New-Brunswick, for Dublin, was abandoned at sea. The crew has reached Liverpool.

HARTFORD, Nov. 3.--The official report of the Connecticut State Board of Health for September, just issued, shows a decided decrease in mortality for September over August. Among unusual causes of death is one from nose-bleed, in NewBritain, and one from lockjaw, in Meridan.
LONDON, Nov. 4.--Berlin dispatch says: "Famine is feared in Northern Russia because of the failure of crops."

LONDON, Nov. 4.--The Manchester Guardian, in its commercial article, this morning, says: "The market is quiet, with small business. Where sellers are slightly easier to deal with considerable sales are occasionally effected, especially of some descriptions of export years, chiefly for China and the Levant. The cloth market is steady."

The only new development in the Newark bank failure yesterday was the arrest of Henry B. Marchbank, a former clerk of the bank, on a charge of having, between two and three years ago, embezzled about $50,000 of the bank's moneys. The first intimation of this embezzlement is said to have come from Cashier Baldwin himself.

In the Brooklyn Navy-yard there is only one ship at present preparing to go into commission, the Brooklyn, which is ordered to the SouthAtlantic squadron, where it will serve as flag-ship for Rear-Admiral Spotts. The ship was to have been commissioned on Nov. 2, but delays have occurred which make it improbable that she will be ready for sea before the end of next week.

LONDON, Nov. 4.--The British steamer Scio, Capt. Thomson, from Savannah Oct. 9, for Reval, has put into Plymouth. She reports having experienced heavy weather. Her chart-house was washed away, bride damaged, boats stove, and stanchions started.

Following is the text of Lord Lorne's address at Quebec upon embarking for England: MESSIEURS: I thank you with all my heart for coming to wish me bon voyage. Although anxious after a long separation to see my friends, I leave Canada, though it be only for a short time, with regret. It is you who have made my stay here so regret.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8.--The Hon. Benjamin Harris Brewster closed the argument to-day in the star route case on behalf of the Government. The court-room was crowded by members of the Bar and prominent Government officials who were attracted by the high reputation of Mr. Brewster as a lawyer and forensic orator, and who listened attentively to his masterly argument.

BONNY, Africa, Oct. 28.--Reports from New-Calabar indicate that another war is imminent there between king Amakree and Will Braid. Several sanguinary contests have already occurred between the followers of both parties. The powerful chiefs Oko Jumbo and Jaja intend to join in the hostilities, the former siding with Will Braid and the latter with King Amakree.

The Republican General Committee of Kings County met last evening in Central Hall, Fulton-street, Brooklyn. The attendance of members was large, and the room was crowded with Republicans anxious to learn what action would be taken on the resignation of Jacob Worth which it was generally understood had been tendered.

Mr. Thuslow Weed became 84 years of age yesterday, and from early morning up to the dinner hour he received the congratulations of many visitors. Flowers, arranged in every imaginable fanciful shape, were sent to him, hearing cards with words of affectionate remembrance.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Nov. 16.--A construction train, with a party of laborers, on the California southern Railroad, jumped the track near the summit of the soledad grade, yesterday morning. The flat cars loaded with ties upset, falling on the men, instantly killing one and badly crushing five more, two of whom can hardly recover.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The attendance of spectators in the court-room this morning shows that public curiosity is increasing, and that the desire to witness the proceedings is daily growing stronger in the higher classes of the community.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16.--The second day of the Fall meeting of the National Fair Association was more successful than the first. There were four races, all of which were well contested.

BOSTON, Nov. 16.--The Missionary Conference of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society continued this morning at Trinity Church. The holy communion was administered in Bishop Paddock's church. The music was by a choir of clergymen. Bishop Whipple, of Minnesota, and the Rev. Drs. Coolidge and Twing assisted Bishop Paddock in conducting the services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18.--The contest over the Collectorship of Internal Revenue in the Pittsburg district bas been renewed. Last spring an effort was made to secure the removal of the present Collector, Thomas W. Davis, and the appointment of Frank P. Case, but President Garfield declined to make the change. Davis has held office for 12 years, and has a good record as an officer.

The Rev. Mr. FROTHINGHAM has lately made an announcement of a change in his religious views which has attracted a great deal of attention. It has been warmly welcomed by certain religious journals, who fancy that the late heresiarch is about to return to a, belief in Christianity, and it has been viewed with some alarm by the FreeReligionists, who have hitherto been proud of his boldness and eloquence.

An accident causing serious injury to four bricklayers occured at about 11 o'clock yesterday morning at the Mills Building now in process of erection at Broad-street and Exchange place. WASHINGTON, Nov. 21.--The attempt made on Saturday on the life of Guiteau had the effect to swell the crowd in attendance at the trial today. One hour before the court convened, the crowd was so great about the court-house that the services of a squad of policemen were required to force a passage for the admission of the jury.
LONDON, Nov. 21.--Miss Gafford, holder of two small forms, was found dead in bed at Wexford yesterday, Marks on her neck indicate that she was murdered. The motive is supposed to have been robbery.

NEW-HAVEN, Nov. 23.--Jailer Stevens, in obedience to a writ of habeas corpus, brought James and Walter Malley before Judge Beardsley, in the Superior Court, this forenoon, when their counsel made arguments for admitting the prisoners to bail. For the first time since their arrest in the latter part of August, Tilton E. Doolittle, the State's Attorney, appeared in the case.

Mme. Patti's concert last night at Steinway Hall, at the reduced prices announced, was a great popular success. The hall was filled in every part, and the enthusiasm was all that any singer could expect.

The Supreme Court yesterday decided the case of Oscar Mueller against the State in favor of the defendant. Henry Ford as Police Justices, an active canvass has been carried on for the purpose of securing action at to-day's meeting of the board on the nominations which are now pending before the Aldermen.

On the 16th of September last Charles Becker and Nathan Marks were arrested at a house in East New-York on a charge of forging and uttering one-thousand-franc notes on the Bank of France. Becker is an expert forger, well known to the Police.
BERLIN, Nov. 28.--In the Reichstag today debate was begun on the project for the incorporation of Hamburg in the Zollverein.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--Political matters in this city are in a state of active ferment. The developments of fraud in the Tax Office made last week have had a stimulating effect on the Citizens' Committee of One Hundred, and it is working zealously to get the "Reform" Party in shape to carry the municipal election next February.

Michael Hackett, an ex-Park policeman, who shot and killed his wife, Marian, at One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, between Broadway and Tenth-avenue, on May 11 last, was convicted, in the General Sessions Court, of murder in the second degree.

BOSTON, Nov. 28.--The Directors of the Pacific National Bank have held an extended session to-day, the meeting not being adjourned until 10:30 P.M. When Controller Knox suspended the appointment of a Receiver for one week, it was upon the condition that Examiner Needham should have charge of the bank in the interim.

The last General Assembly of South Carolina appointed a joint committee of its two branches to prepare measures for the registration of voters and the regulation of elections, and to make a report at the session which has now begun.

The National Tariff Convention will open at 10 o'clock this morning in the large hall of the Cooper Union. The officers of the Executive Committee and the Secretary and his assistants were busy at the St. Nicholas Hotel yesterday and last ...

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28.--About a week ago a great sensation was created in legal and judicial circles by the discovery that all the ballots cast at the municipal election last February, with the exception of those from two wards, had been burned by order of the City Commissioners, though the law provides that they shall be preserved for one year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28.--The several candidates for Speaker were not supplied today with much new material to work upon, the number of members who arrived being provokingly small.

A meeting of subscribers to the Mutual Fire Insurance Company was held yesterday in room No. 18 in the New-York Life Insurance Company Building, at No. 345 Broadway. William H. Lee, of Lee, Tweedy Co., was the Chairman and ...
GENTLEMEN: I have the honor to present to you a list of the articles which, during the fiscal year of 1880, paid a higher duty than 80 per cent and not over 97 per cent, ad valorem:

The annual holiday opening at R.H. Macy Co.'s, Fourteenth-street and Sixth-Avenue, took place yesterday, and throughout the day the large stores were thronged with a crowd of sight-seers to examine the recently received novelties and importations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--The members of the star route ring and their friends do not conceal their expectation that in some way they will be able to undo the good work of Postmaster-General James in the contract division of the Post Office Department and secure the restoration of service expedition upon the ring routes in the territories and elsewhere.

The failure of the David Warwick Porkpacking Company, limited, at No. 210 East One Hundred and Twentieth-street, is announced. The company was incorporated in October, 1880, with a capital of $50,000, and bought out the business of David Warwick for $40,000.

Mr. Maurice Grau's French Opera Company made its first appearance Monday night, after a successful tour in Cuba and South America, in "Madame Favart," an opera so familiar as not to call for special notice. Last night "Si J'Etais Roi" was played for the first time in this country. The work is by Adolph Adam, and is about 30 years old, having been produced in Paris in 1851.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 29.--An affray occurred in the penitentiary at this city to-day between McDaniels and Lambert, two convicts, in which the latter beat the former to death with the box of a wheel. McDaniels was an old man, while Lambert is only 35 years old.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--It being generally understood that the prisoner would be put on the stand to-day to testify in his own behalf, the crowd, which flocked toward the Court-house as early as 9 o'clock, far surpassed in numbers that of any previous day.
LONDON, Nov. 29.--Lord Lorne, Governor-General of Canada, and the Princess Louise, are visiting the Queen at Windsor Castle to-day.

WELLINGTON, Kan., Nov. 29.--Mr. Danford, the owner of the banks at Hunnewell and Caldwell which were recently closed, and Mr. Smith, his Cashier, were arrested to-day and brought to this city on the charge of receiving deposits after they knew the banks to be insolvent and must close.

Bellport, Long Island, having survived its first church scandal, has settled down once more to duck-shooting and the more peaceful pursuit of preparing fuel for the Winter's fires. The great question, however, which has agitated the town from centre to circumference whether the Presiding Elder of the African Methodist Episcopal ...

BERLIN, Nov. 29.--In the Reichstag, to-day, discussion on the second reading of the budget was begun. Prince Bismarck repeatedly spoke. He declared that he had advanced, while the Progressist Party were inclined to put on a drag. He said he adhered more firmly to his economical policy in proportion as he saw the radical elements obtaining the lead in the Liberal Party.

After recess, when Chairman Loring had called the convention to order, with a considerably reduced attendance in the hall, the Committee on Permanent Organization reported the name of Senator Warner Miller, of New-York, for permanent Chairman, and a long list of Vice-Presidents, including A.S.
