Two additional deaths from small-pox were reported in Jersey City yesterday.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Nov. 29.--The formal opening of the ninth convention of the National Butter, Cheese and Egg Association took place this afternoon in Green's Opera-house. The attendance was large. The convention was called to order by J.I. Snauffer, President of the local committee; Mayor Smith welcomed the delegates, and, ...

ALBANY, Nov. 29.--There were filed here to-day articles of consolidation of the Rochester and Pittsburg, Rochester and Charlotte, Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg, Great Valley and Bradford, Bradford and State Line, and Pittsburg and New-York Railroad Companies; capital stock, $10,000,000.

NEWBURG, Nov. 30.--The projected centennial celebration at Newburg in the Fall of 1883, which has already been mentioned in THE TIMES, cannot but commend itself to any one acquainted with the occasion that exists for such an observance. The events which it will commemorate are second in importance to none of the many momentous ones which make up the history of the Revolutionary era.
LONDON, Nov. 29.--A farmer named O'Cornish has been found beaten to death near Dromore, County Down. One arrest has been made in connection with the affair.

Coroner Herrman's investigation into the falling of the buildings at Grand-street and South Fifth-avenue was resumed yesterday morning. Edwin Dobbs, who has been a practical builder for 40 years, testified that he had not seen the buildings in question before or after the disaster.

The new White Star steam-ship Coptic, which is soon to arrive at this port, was built at the yard of Harland Wolff, Belfast, Ireland, from which all of the White Star vessels were launched. The Coptic is not quite so large as the Germanic, but is very much like that steam-ship in appearance.

LONDON, Nov. 29.--The Hamburg-American Line steamer Lessing, Capt. Voss, which sailed from Hamburg Nov. 16, for New-York, was towed into Plymouth at 1:45 o'clock this afternoon. She is strained and broke her rudder-head in two places on the 23d inst. The passengers are well. It was difficult to keep the water out of the ship while the engines were stopped.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 29.--The October report of the State Board of Health, issued to-day, shows an unusual prevalence during the month of diphtheria in Hartford and Waterbury, there having been three deaths in one family in the latter place. The disease has prevailed malignantly in other parts of the State, notably in Naugatuck, Salisbury, Manchester, and Hampton.

A multitude of blue-eyed, rosy-cheeked, and wavy-haired dolls, all charmingly attired in silks, satins, and laces, began a public reception in Republican Hall, No. 55 West Thirty-third-street, yesterday afternoon. The hall had been fitted up for the event with admirable taste and ingenuity, and the spectacle presented was quite a brilliant one.

Many of the streets on the East Side of the city have been repaved during the last two years, the old cobble-stones being replaced by the new granite block pavement, which, when properly laid, forms a smooth and easy roadway, and should last for many years. The work, however, in many cases, has not been properly done, and some of the streets in which block pavement has been laid ...

A meeting of representatives of various mercantile and commercial bodies, for the purpose of discussing the means and methods by which the passage of a national bankruptcy law may be passed at the next session of Congress was held last night at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel.

The first appearance of Little Corinne at the Metropolitan Casino was postponed to this afternoon, when she will appear in the "Magic Slipper." Mr. Werrenrath's last vocal recital will take place Thursday afternoon at the hall of the Brooklyn Historical Society.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 29.--The conference of Liberal members-elect of the Legislature and a few other prominent leaders of that party, held last night, resulted in a perfect understanding as to the policy to be carried out by the incoming Legislature.

A handsome, dark-complexioned little girl, quick of movement and vivacious in manner, was taken before Judge Donohue, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, by Mr. E. Fellows Jenkins, the Superintendent of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

PARIS, Nov. 29.--The Chamber of Deputies has annulled the election of M. de la Villegontier, Monarchist, as member for Fougeres, in the Department of Ille-et-Vilaine, by a vote of 379 to 86, on the ground of clerical influence.
Whatever may have been involved in the recent election in Virginia more than the debt question, it is evident that so far as that question is concerned the Readjusters claim the victory as their own.

A suit for breach of promise of marriage, in which the plaintiff seeks to recover $25,000 damages for the injury to her affections and her disappointment generally, was on trial yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, before Judge Wallace and a jury.
A meeting of the Chamber of Commerce will be held to-morrow afternoon at 1 o'clock. The steam-ship State of Florida, of the State Line, from Glasgow, landed 230 immigrants at Castle Garden yesterday.

Time was when tender beef was attainable--beef that was juicy, well garnished with fat, and hardly to be spoiled even by overcooking. Now the man who finds a piece of tender beef draws the rarest of prizes in the butcher's lottery. Beef is uniformly tough.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Nov. 29.--The ninth annual session of the American Public Health Association convened to-day at Masonic Temple. There was a large attendance. The meeting was called to order by the President, Dr. Charles B. White.

The hall was but about half full when the Chairman called the convention to order in the evening, and the size of the audience did not increase materially during the evening. One of the Secretaries announced that a meeting of the delegates representing the iron-ore producers would be held in Room No. 24, Cooper Union, at 9:30 o'clock this morning.

Mr. Cyrus W. Field is very mad. In his evening organ yesterday he insolently assailed Mr. Brayton Ives, one of the Governors of the NewYork Stock Exchange, who recently had the hardihood to criticise in the columns of THE TIMES certain transactions of Mr. Field, and Mr. Field's colleagues, Gould and Sage, in the matter of Metropolitan stamped stock.

The trial which is now going on at Washington is in some respects one of the most remarkable on record. Considering all the circumstances attending GUITEAU's crime and the consequences which followed it, cool-headed people were justified in apprehending that the criminal would be overwhelmed with public detestation and hurried through a formal trial to a speedy doom.

Mrs. Isabel F. McCready, a depositor in the Mechanics' National Bank of Newark, has, by her attorney, addressed a note to Receiver Frelinghuysen, calling upon him to bring suit against the stockholders, claiming that their responsibility should be regarded as an asset. The Receiver holds the matter under advisement. The assessments against the stock of the bank have thus far yielded $175,000.

The annual meeting of the New-York, Lake Erie and Western Railroad Company was held yesterday. President Jewett had everything his own way, no opposition of any sort appearing. The old Board of Directors, Mr. Jewett presiding, decided to declare a 6 per cent. dividend on preferred stock and to pay the coupons on income bonds.

BOSTON, Nov. 29.--The meeting of the Directors and large stockholders of the Pacific Bank to-day, to consider the situation, was long in session. President Benyon and the broker, Weeks, whose failure brought the bank affairs to a crisis, were both present.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 29.--The Grand Jury today found indictments against Alderman John J. Kelly and Councilman A.J. Patton on the charge of asking bribes. Some time ago an ordinance was introduced into the Board of Aldermen, and hurriedly passed its first reading, which provides for the condemnation of a part of Culvert-street.

The Hon. Andrew D. White, President of Cornell University, read the paper before the NewYork Historical Society, last evening, on the celebration of its seventy-seventh anniversary. The Brick Church, Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventhstreet, was comfortably filled by the members and their friends.

Inspector Waddy, who has been connected with the Police Department of Brooklyn for over 30 years, is about to retire on half-pay. Mr. Waddy has been confined to his house by sickness for several months.

The National Tariff Convention met in the large hall of the Cooper Union yesterday morning, and having chosen the Hon. George B. Loring, of Massachusetts, temporary Chairman, and listened to an address by him, effected a permanent organization, with Senator Warner Miller as Chairman, and during the afternoon and evening listened to discussions of tariff questions, all from the protectionist stand-point.

The Prince of Wales has now not only made the grand tour of the world, he has, in a sense, made the grand tour of life itself. Every moment it has been said, is travel, if rightly understood. The Prince has traveled everywhere, literally as well as metaphorically, and has seen everything. He has had extraordinary opportunities of reviewing existence in all its departments and aspects.

Miss Bessie Hamilton Morgan, a daughter of Mr. Edward Morgan, the banker, was married at 2:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon to August Belmont, Jr., in the Church of the Ascension, corner Fifth-avenue and Tenth-street, by the Rev. John Cotton Smith.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29.--Secretary Hunt gave out for publication to-day the annual reports of the bureau officers of the Navy Department. Chief English, of the Bureau of Equipment and Recruiting, reports that during the year 69 vessels were wholly or partially equipped at the several navy-yards and stations at an expenditure for labor of $83,094 07, and for material of $355,807 79.

The Hon. Mr. KELLEY, of Pennsylvania, delivered the principal address last evening before the so-called "Tariff Convention." The most striking feature of the veteran protectionist's address was that it contained only a vague, remote, incidental allusion to the tariff.

An active speculation has recently been going on in the shares of the Hudson Bay Company, and a good many inquiries have arisen as to the cause of their advanced prices. It is due, we believe, to speculations upon the future value of the company's lands in the North-west.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 30.--Two negroes became involved in a drunken brawl at John Burke's store, in Twiggs County, in which John Lowe was fatally stabbed. The murderer has been arrested, and is in jail at Irwinton.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 30.--A special from Jacksonville, Texas, says: "A boiler explosion occurred at Douglass Son's mill, at Mud Creek, yesterday, killing three white men--the engineer, Oliver Wilson, and two laborers named Burkell and Billips--and fatally injuring a colored man. The mill was blown to atoms."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 30.--At a largely attended meeting of the Yale University Boat Club this evening the challenge of Harvard to row an eight-oared race at New-London neat Summer, the date to be agreed upon hereafter, was considered.
LONDON, Nov. 30.--The survivors of the Calf Rock Light-house disaster are still upon the rock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--The report of the Naval Advisory Board on the reorganization of the Navy was made public to-day. The recommendations contained in the report have received the indorsement of Secretary Hunt, and the report itself is appended to the annual report of the Secretary, which has been submitted to the President.

Hospital Sunday this year will fall on Dec. 25, Christmas, and hospital Saturday on the day preceding. At no time should the generous impulses of the charitable be more thoroughly aroused than during the joyous season of the Christmas holidays, when all men are seeking to provide good cheer for their friends and "good-will to men" is the one sentiment which inspires the community.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30.--Some of the nearest friends of the President assert that they are still in the dark so far as his selection of new members of the Cabinet is concerned.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30.--It was anticipated this morning in railroad circles of Cleveland that the Cleveland, Mount Vernon and Columbus Railroad Company would be effectually reorganized before evening, but the expectation has, so far, come to naught. Those in charge say that final steps will be taken, and the company formed, on Thursday.

DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 5.--An old German milk vendor named Christian Ternes was brutally murdered last night by Charles Martin, a young iron-molder. Martin was arrested, but pretends that he knows nothing about the murder.

Last month in Vienna died a man who is believed to have been the last surviving pupil of Beethoven. His name was Karl Friedrich Hirsch, his age 80, and in his native land he was not without considerable reputation as a composer. Shortly before he died he had just completed an offertory for tenor, which, in a letter to a friend, he described as his " Schwanengosang".

INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 11.--A four-story building on South Meriden-street, occupied by F. Stout Son, wholesale grocers, fell in this morning. The accident, it is supposed, was caused by the heavy weights on the upper stories. The building is a total wreck and the goods are considerably damaged. There was no one on the premises at the time of the occurrence.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, Dec. 11.--News has been received here of the loss, off the coast of Cuba, of the bark Maple Leaf, of this port, from Antwerp, for New-Orleans, with railroad iron. The vessel was owned by Troop Son and others.

The eighteeth anniversary of the Lexington Avenue Baptist Church was celebrated by three services yesterday in the church edifice at One Hundred and Tenth-street and Lexington-avenue. The morning serison was preached by the Rev. E. Dodge, President of Madison University.

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--Superintendent Eaton and a corps of assistants were at work until midnight last night in putting the Senate and Assembly Chamber in readiness for Tuesday. Many improvements have been made in the Senate Chamber. The pitch of both galleries has been lowered, and it is possible now for visitors to descend without the fear of plunging head over heels upon the floor below.
The body of Francis McCue, who was drowned on Saturday night by falling from a scow at the foot of East Twentieth-street, was recovered yesterday.

Among many good things in Punch's Almanack there is one particularly excellent sketch by Mr. Du Maurier. It represents a poet-rather a limp and amateur poet. He has just written, "with immense labor," a sonnet which he ventures to think not unworthy of Milton or Shakespeare, and be proposes to read it to his wife.

Underwriters await the announcement of the new year with peculiar, almost painful, anxiety. Until the death of the old year is consummated they are keenly aware of the possibility that at the eleventh hour a fire may occur destroying, not only the profits of 12 months' careful business and wiping out surplus accumulations, but impairing their capital and credit beside.

ALBANY, Jan. 1.--A large majority of the members-elect to both houses are now in town, including all the Democratic Senators except Homer A. Nelson. The subject of the organization has been the main topic of discussion through the day, but no progress has been made toward a settlement of the question on any basis that will secure united action between the Tammany faction and the regular Democrats.

Railways made rapid progress in Northern India during the Afghan war, and now it is proposed that two others shall be built, not, however, for purposes of defense against Afghan chiefs, but as aids against the famine. ALBANY, Jan. 1.--The Democratic Assemblymen will hold their caucus in the Assembly Chamber to-morrow night at 8 o'clock, two hours later than that of the Senators. Invitations will be sent to the Tammany members so that no fault on that point can be found by them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31.--The histories of the mail routes, by means of which Brady and the star route ring plundered the Treasury, have been told in THE TIMES, and the methods of the ring have been fully exposed. In each history the sums awarded to the members of the ring have been stated.

In a quarrel among desperate colored men yesterday morning in a drinking saloon at No. 158 West Thirtieth-street, Isaac Willroy, a waiter, was shot and killed by Samuel Thomas. The saloon is kept by, Robert A. Caskie, and is a noted resort for colored men of bad character. Willroy was 29 years of age, and lived with his wife in the rear of No. 258 West Twenty-eighth-street.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 1, 1882. The annual estimate by the Director of the Mint of the values of foreign coins for 1882 makes only two changes from the values as shown in the Treasury circular of Jan. 1, 1881. The Austrian florin and the Japanese yen are each reduced 1 mill. The gourde, the monetary unit of Hayti, is added to the list of foreign,coins, and its valuation placed at 96.5 cents.

The strains of a beautiful new organ greeted the early arrivals in the Fifth-Avenue Baptist Church yesterday morning. Although not yet completed, the instrument was in a condition to be used for accompanying the congregation in singing the hymns. The old organ, on the opposite side of the church, was used in following the quartet choir in the rendition of figured music.

The steam-boat Newport, belonging to the Fall River Line, was run into and seriously damaged by a small schooner, about half way between Point Judith and Watch Hill, early yesterday morning. The Newport, commanded by Capt. Abraham G. Simmons, left Newport at 1:05 o'clock yesterday morning, with about 150 passengers for this City.

Yesterday, representing as it did New Year's Day in a festive sense, must have been hailed with delight by all bent upon enjoying it as a day in every way suitable for the occasion. The man who could have complained of the weather was certainly not in harmony with the season.

The fire at John A. Lord Son's tannery, in Peabody, Mass., Sunday night, destroyed the bark-mill and hide department and badly damaged the currying-shop. The buildings contained a large stock in various stages of manufacture, and a lot of goods belonging to other concerns, all of which were burned. The loss is $50,000; insured in local companies for $35,000.

During the two hours devoted by Seth Low, the incoming Mayor, and James Howell, Jr., the outgoing Mayor, to receiving calls in the Brooklyn City Hall, nearly 1,500 citizens entered the Mayor's office and tendered congratulations to both gentlemen. The new Mayor stood the hand-shaking process very well and had a pleasant word for every visitor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--There is quite a flutter among those clerks, mostly women, in the Treasury Department who are carried on what is called the "lapse fund," as it has been discovered since Secretary Folger came in that that fund has been overdrawn, and it has been ordered that employes on the "lapse fund roll" shall be dropped until the amount overdrawn shall be made up.

On the southern shore of Staten Island, at what is known as Seguine Point, there rises from the beach a small stone sea wall which extends for little more than a dozen rods. This protects from the inundating waters a small plot of ground surrounded by an unpainted picket fence. Inside this inclosure little straggling boards mark some hundreds of low turf-covered mounds.

Yesterday was, on the whole, the best New Year's Day for theatrical managers they have known for years, and generally the houses were well patronized, especially in the galleries. There was no matinee at the Union-Square Theatre, but in the evening every seat, was sold and many would-be patrons were turned away.

The case of Denman against Cripps, which was decided in the Chancery Division yesterday, and was characterized by Mr. Justice Kay as in some respects one of the most important that ever came before a court of justice, might well furnish material for a new "Nicholas Nickleby."

The tug-boat Leader, Capt. John A. Brandow, started from Red Hook for Poughkeepsie with the schooner Daisy Parker in tow about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. An hour later, when between Governor's and Bedloe's Islands, the deckhand rushed up and informed Capt. Brandow that the boat was on fire.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Jan. 2.--Details have just been received of the calamity that occurred at Shanesville, Tuscarawas County, late Saturday night. The Knights or Pythias were diving a festival in Henry Goeler's hall, which was in the second story of his store building. The building was originally a brick one of two stories and a cellar basement.

A dejeuner a la fourchette was given yesterday afternoon at 1 o'clock by Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at her residence, No. 319 Fifth-avenue, in honor of the members of the French delegation, who returned Sunday from their tour in the South. No cards were issued, but the guests came in response to personal invitations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2.--Guiteau was allowed to see about 200 callers yesterday, who were allowed to go as far as the door of his cell. Many of them were women. Guiteau's general invitation to the public to call on him attracted a good many persons to the jail. For a good part of the day the ante-room was full of men and women waiting for an opportunity to be conducted into his presence.

ALBANY, Jan. 2.--The observance of New Year's Day has been general throughout the city. The morning was the coldest of the Winter thus far. Those who climbed the hill to the Capitol where Gov. Cornell was receiving visitors encountered a cold, penetrating blast that chilled everything before it.
CALCUTTA, Jan. 2.--The Ameer of Afghanistan arrived at Cabul on the 16th of December. BERLIN, Jan. 2.--The appointment of Gen. Count Waldersee as ad latus to Gen. von Moltke is gazetted.

DUBLIN, Jan. 2.--Dawson was to-day formally inaugurated Lord Mayor of Dublin. The Corporation, by a vote of 28 to 18, refused to pass the customary vote of thanks to Mr. George Moyers, the retiring Lord Mayor, in consequence of his refusal to convene a special meeting of the Corporation to confer the freedom of the city on Messrs. Parnell and Dillon. Mr. Moyers was hissed in the streets by a mob.

Grave fears are entertained in Greece for the future of Chios. The island is said to be continually sinking, and there are reasons to believe that in time its entire surface may disappear from human sight. Capt. Ball, of the British bark Okenburg, which arrived from Maceio yesterday, reports a stormy passage of 37 days.

The impressive funeral ceremonies of the Independent Order of Odd-fellows were held yesterday afternoon over the remains of the late Joseph Patterson, who died on the 1st inst. at the age of 92 years.

The official canvass made yesterday of the election returns for State officers indicates that Gen. L.F. Hubbard has, without any reasonable doubt, been elected Governor of the State. His majority mounts up to the comfortable figure of 27,857.

The Board of Policy Justices held an adjourned meeting at Jefferson market Court last evening to further consider the question of the clerical appointments for the year 1882. Last year the Board of Estimate and Apportionment gave the Board of Justices $32,000 for salaries of assistant clerks.

On the night of Nov. 10 John Winn, who keeps a bakery at No. 555 West Thirty-secondstreet, was awakened by hearing a burglar in his room. He pursued the intruder, who, finding himself closely cornered, jumped from the window to the yard below.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 9.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad Company was held here to-day. The old Board of Directors was re-elected, with the substitution of Benjamin F. Newcomer for Samuel Harian. Isaac Hinckley was re-elected President, A.J. Cassatt Vice-President, and Robert Craven Treasurer.

Hague's troupe of British Operatic Ministrels entered last evening upon the second week of their sojourn in the City, and drew a large audience to the Metropolitan Casino, which is admirably adapted to their entertainment. The company numbers 26 members, who are seen in pleasing series of songs and characterizations.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 9.--The bark Lady Dufferin, (British,) which cleared from this port for Liverpool, arrived at Port Royal to-day in distress. Her rudder was gone and she had been drifting 18 days.
ST. LOUIS, Jan. 9.--George H. Crane was arrested here this afternoon for forging the name of A.L. Hopkins, First Vice-President of the Wabash Railroad, and obtaining passes under false pretenses.

EASTON, Penn., Jan. 9.--Charles Jennings, a man of middle age, with a wife and three children, who formerly lived in Bethlehem, where he was well known, was killed last night on the Easton and Amboy Road by falling from a freight car and being run over. He was working as brakeman until he could obtain work at his trade--paperhanging--and this was his third trip on the road.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 9.--Gen. Robert Lowry was to-day installed as Governor of Mississippi. The inauguration ceremonies were very imposing, and were witnessed by a very large assemblage, all parts of the State being represented among the spectators.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 9.--The Atlanta Constitution to-morrow morning will print the Hon. W.H. Felton's reply to points set forth in an interview with Senator Ben Hill, published in the same journal a few days ago.

HAVANA, Jan. 9.--Don Bernardo Portuondo, the Deputy to the Cortes, who is now is Cuba, has been authorized by a French house to contract for the construction of a railroad from Santa Clara to Santiago de Cuba, the link necessary to complete, with existing lines, a central road traversing the entire length of the island.

The rooms of the vaccinating corps were thronged yesterday by men, women, and children desirous of securing the protection of a pure and wholesome vaccination, and over 200 persons were vaccinated.
The new iron steam-ship City of Puebla, of the Alexandre Line, was examined by a small party of invited guests yesterday. This vessel appears to be a thoroughly stanch one.

Nowhere else has a party "boss" exhibited a tithe of the power that the elder CAMERON exercised for years in that great State.

ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 9.--The building of the International Cotton Exposition, at Oglethorpe Park, was sold to-day at private sale by the Executive Committee to F.P. Rice and R.H. Richards, of Atlanta, for $25,000 cash. The sale is considered a good one, and the purchasers will at once organize a joint stock company to fill the building with machinery for the manufacture of cotton.

KINGSTON, Jan. 9.--The body of Mrs. Katie Grimes, who has been missing from her home in this city under peculiar circumstances for several weeks, was found floating in the Rondont Creek, near the Powell dock, yesterday morning. No marks of violence were found, and it is supposed the woman committed suicide by drowning in the creek, although no cause for the act seems to be known.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 9.--A special to the News from Courtney says: "Three negroes were arrested near Graball yesterday for the murder of another negro named Jordan. The negroes confessed the murder, and guided by their directions, the body of the murdered man was found, with the head cut off and otherwise mutilated. The citizens threaten summary justice to the murderers.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 9.--S. Cravan, formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y., was sent from this city today to the State asylum at St. Peter. He was arrested last Thursday while wandering through the streets proclaiming that Christ had risen, and that he was the messenger of Jesus Christ on earth, and intended to run things to suit himself hereafter. He was adjudged insane, and the court ordered that he be sent to the asylum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--The Republicans of North Carolina, are excited about a proposed change in the office of Internal Revenue Collector in the Sixth District of that State, and the representatives of the candidates are here in force, pressing their respective claims before Commissioner Raum and the Secretary of the Treasury.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Jan. 9.--An accident occurred in West Genesee-street a few minutes after 1 o'clock this afternoon by which three persons lost their lives, two were fatally injured, and ten seriously wounded. At No. 34 West Genesee-street is situated the saloon and restaurant of Cornelius Tracy, a two-story rear and three-story front brick building.

BOSTON, Jan. 9.--George W. Bristol was arrested here to-day and lodged in jail in default of $10,000, on a charge of bigamy. Bristol is an agent of a mercantile agency in Detroit, his head-quarters being at No. 66 Wall-street, New-York.
CATLETSBURG, Ky., Jan. 9.--The Grand Jury was impaneled to-day under a special act of the Kentucky Legislature convening the court to try the Ashland murderers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9.--Rear-Admiral Spotts, commanding the South Atlantic station, in a letter to the Secretary of the Navy, dated Montevideo, Dec. 1, states that during the stay of the Shenandoah at Buenos Ayres salutes were exchanged with the national authorities, and that in company with Minister Osborne he made official visits to the President of the Argentine Republic and the Minister of War and Marine.
KINGSTON, N.Y., Jan. 9.--Much interest is felt here in regard to who shall receive the appointment of Postmaster for the Kingston uptown office.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9.--At noon to-day the Master appointed by the Court ef Common Pleas to act as Chairman of the annual meeting of the Philadelphia and Reading Railroad Company called the meeting to order in Association Hall, which was about half filled in the lower part of the auditorium.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9.--Frederick Miller was bitten by a small dog four months ago. He brooded over it until he was seized with all the symptoms of hydrophobia on Thursday last. He died at a late hour last night.
At 3:42 o'clock Sunday afternoon 20 homing pigeons belonging in Taunton, Mass., and Boston, were liberated by the National Columbarian Society from the corner of Ninth-street and Broadway.

ALBANY Jan. 9.--A question having recently been raised respecting the right of savings banks to invest in the bonds of tha State of Georgia, the Bank Superintendent has given official constriction to the law on the subject, declaring such investment to be clearly illegal and unauthorized and in opposition to both the letter and the spirit of the General Savings Bank act.
The monthly meeting of the New-York Association for the Protection of Game was held last evening at Pinard's.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 9.--Gen. Terry in his report for the Department of Dakota, says: "The Indian outlook in Northern Montana is unfavorable. Buffalo are rapidly diminishing, the Indians are making raids on the cattle, and the ranchmen are organizing for protection."

Capt. Neilsen, of the Norwegian bark Vega, which arrived from Pernambuce yesterday, reports that on Dec. 31, in latitude 34 50' and longitude 68 54', a violent gale set in and continued for four days.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 11.--At the inquest today on the body of Frederick Miller, who was reported to have died from hydrophobia last Saturday, the attending physician testified that the death resulted more from the fear of being affected with hydrophobia than from the actual presence of the disease, and that death ensued through exhaustion, the result of acute mania. WASHINGTON, Jan. 11.--The record in the Flipper court-martial case has reached Judge-Advocate-General Swaim for review. The fact that the record has been referred to the Judge-Advocate-General is almost conclusive evidence that the court-martial recommended his dismissal from the service. That such was the finding of the court is the almost universal impression in Army circles.

CHARLESTON, West Va., Jan. 11.--W.R. Robinson, convicted of the murder of Adam Belcher, of Malden, was sentenced yesterday to be hanged on April 7. After receiving his sentence the prisoner said: "Thank you. I am hanged by Prosecuting Attorney Snyder's mob," (meaning the jury.) He also asked the Judge if he was taking vengeance on him for all the murders committed in the county for the last 10 years.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 12.--Barnes Compton was re-elected State Treasurer by the Legislature to-day for the term of two years. One hundred and fifteen votes were cast in joint convention, of which 70 were for Compton. The Republicans voted for Enoch Pratt, giving him 38 votes. Seven votes were scattering.

A policeman passing the building Nos. 379 and 381 West Twelfth-street soon after 9 o'clock last night noticed smoke streaming through the crevices of the doors and windows. He ran to the nearest alarm-box and sent out an alarm.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Jan. 12.--The Legislature of Wisconsin convened at Madison at noon yesterday. In the Assembly F.L. Gilson was elected Speaker. George B. Burrows was chosen President pro tem. of the Senate.

LONDON, Jan. 12.--Mr. Gladstone has again remitted 10 per cent. of the rentals on his Hawarden estate.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Jan. 12.--At the regular monthly meeting of the Western Nail Association, after a full interchange of views, the card rate was advanced from $2.25 to $2.40 per keg. The attendance was large, and reports on the state of trade most encouraging.

GALVESTON, Texas, Jan. 12.--The track of the Mexican National Railway is now laid to a point 25 miles west of Laredo. An excursion party went out on Jan. 10 from Laredo to the end of the track. The party numbered 200 persons, including the Mayor and several officers of the road. At the present rate of track laying the road will reach Lampasas some time in April. Preparations for freight traffic are being made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 12.--The audience which assembled in the court-room this morning to listen to the opening argument to the jury in the Guiteau case was a large and intelligent one. The Marshal gave the spectators due notice that no one would be permitted to leave until the hour for recess, and, for the purpose of emphasizing his remarks, ordered that the main door be locked.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Jan. 12.--In the habeas corpus case yesterday before Judge Hamm, of the Circuit Court, William J. Vance was admitted to bail in $5,000 upon written evidence previously taken before the Justices. Vance was also brought before Justice Patton yesterday, on a charge of the murder of Warren, and was held to bail in $1,000.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 12.--The House to-day passed Senate bill N0. 50, one of the forerunners of the Riddleberger Debt bill, which provides that all coupons offered in payment of taxes shall first undergo scrutiny before a jury as to their genuineness, and that meanwhile the tax-payer shall pay his taxes in lawful money. The bill now goes to the Governor, and it is expected that it will not be delayed.

NYACK, Jan. 12.--A feeling of dissatisfaction has recently arisen among the members of Post Waldron, G.A.R., of this place, caused by the election of a member to whom several objected as Commander of the post. Owing to the disfavor with which the election of this man was received, he was asked to resign the office, and he refused to do it.

NEW-ORLEANS, Jan. 12.--A dispatch from Little RocK reports the killing of Ross Cunningham, a prominent Indian, at Muscogee, Indian Territory, by the United States Indian Police. Cunningham was intoxicated, and had been disturbing the peace. The Police ordered Cunningham to halt, but he threw a rock at them and turned away, when they fired, shooting him through the heart.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12.--The polling of the Gowen proxies was resumed this morning. It began with the twelve hundred and twentieth vote cast since the polls opened on Monday, and at 11 o'clock the thirteenth hundred was turned. By this time the list of names beginning with V had been completed, and W.H. Vanderbilt's name passed without hearing from his proxies.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 12.--A dispatch from Dallas, Texas, says: "The largest single sale of cotton ever made in the United States was made to-day by M.D. Cleveland. It consisted of 5,725 bales. The consideration in round figures was $290,000. Major A. Rutt Kay purchased it for cash."

BERLIN, Jan. 12.--The three Liberal parties in the Reichstag have finally agreed to present a bill on accident insurance which will meet the Government's views half-way. It is hoped the compromise will be accepted.

EASTON, Penn., Jan. 12.--The body of a man of middle age, well dressed, with the name of Parker or Baker on a silk handkerchief in the pocket, was found dead on the track of the NewJersey Central Road at Ashbury to-day. RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 12.--Mrs. Caroline Richings-Bernard is lying critically ill at her residence, in this city, with the small-pox, and her physicians have faint hope of her recovery. Mrs. Bernard, who is widely known in the musical world, has been living in Richmond for two years, during which time she has been successfully engaged in teaching music.

FILBERT TART.--Grind one-half pound of filbert kernels fine with orange-flower water, mix with one-half pound of powdered sugar; add gradually eight yolks of eggs well beaten, two ounces of flour, and eight whites of eggs beaten firm: spread this paste out into three layers of equal size, threequarters of an inch thick; bake in a moderate oven; spread peach or apricot marmaiade between each layer, and ice with maraschino icing.-- ADOLPHE WURTH, DELMONICO, TWENTY-SIXTHSTREET-SOCIETE CULINAIRE.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--A copy of Gov. Murray's Message to the Legislature of Utah has been received at the Interior Department. Mrs. Ogden Goelet gave a ball at Delmonico's last evening, at which about 300 persons were present. The rooms differed from their usual appearance only in being tastefully decorated with flowers.

The Police Court room in the Brooklyn City Hall was crowded to its utmost capacity yesterday when the case of the people against Ellen H. Cheetham was called by Justice Andrew Walsh. Mrs. Cheetham was arraigned before Justice Walsh last week upon a charge of assaulting her husband, James Cheetham, in their boarding-house at No. 82 Hicks-street, on the 15th of December.

John Mooney, a butcher, was placed on trial in the General Sessions Court yesterday for the murder of his wife, Ellen, on Dec. 9, in the tenement-house No. 551 West Thirty-ninth-street, known as "Hell's Kitchen."

HARRISBURG, Jan. 16.--The Harrisburg Telegraph has been formed into a corporation, and has received a charter under the name of the Harrisburg Publishing Company. The capital stock is $50,000. Charles H. Bergner will be manager, and Thomas H. Wilson editor-in-chief.

The once celebrated oarsman, William Elliott, was one of the firemen of the British steamship Critic, which reached Quarantine from Newcastle, England, late Saturday night. After the steamer had anchored at Quarantine the cover of one of the port coal bunkers was left open, and Elliott fell into it as he was walking along the dock in the darkness.

Burnand--one of the electric lights of the British drama, an institution which Stands in need of illumination.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 16.--To-day at 12:30 o'clock Jesse Williams, only 17 years of age, was hanged for the murder, in July last, of an old man, Toby Lark. On Thursday last he made full confession of the crime, was baptized, and declared himself ready to die. His last night was composed and comfortable. This morning he awoke from quiet sleep and requested that he be hanged not later than 12:30.

Mr. Pinero has written a successful play for the St. James's. All the critics discovered hat the scenery and characters of the piece, the central figure, and the motive of the action were like Thomas Hardy's "Far From the Madding Crowd."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--The National Board of Health reports on small-pox to-day as follows: For the week ending Jan. 7, 1 death in Buffalo and 17 deaths in Hudson County, N.J. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 16.--At 9 P.M. the river was rising at the rate of 1 inch per hour. It is now (11 P.M.) 50 feet 1 inch on the gauge. A steady rain is prevailing. Nearly 600 families have been driven from their homes.

Grenville Murray had been long in illhealth at the time of his death recently in Paris. For more than a year he had suffered from a severe form of dyspepsia, which prevented his taking solid food, so that his death was practically the result of a gradual wasting away. He took to his bed about a fortnight before his death, being compelled so to do from pure exhaustion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 16.--Among the rumors in connection with the Guiteau trial is the prediction that the juryman Bright will "hang the jury" on the ground that Guiteau is insane. Mr. Bright's father was for several years an inmate of the Government Asylum for the Insane here, and died in that institution. The same authority avezs that the son has always been considered by his intimates a "very peculiar man."

LONDON, Jan. 16.--Edward Hanian, the oarsman, arrived at Queenstown this afternoon on the steamer City of Chester and proceeded to Liverpool, whence he will go direct to London. He will be entertained at a dinner at the Aquarium on Saturday. He is in perfect health.

BERLIN, Jan. 16.--An association is being formed here for the promotion of bi-metallic currency in Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--A bill was introduced in the Senate to-day by Mr. Blair, to grant a pension to Mrs. Garfield of $5,000 a year, from Sept. 19, 1881.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Jan. 17.--The commission appointed at the last session of the State Legislature to compute the vote for State Treasurer cast at the last election met at noon to-day. All the Senators and members of the House comprising the Returning Board were present. The time occupied in the proceedings was about one hour and a half. No mistake was found in the majority for Baily.
ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 17.--The budget for 1882 is officialy published. The totals of the revenue and expenditure are made to bal ance, both being 762,000,000 rubles.

EASTON, Penn., Jan. 17.--The members of the Northampton County Bar have extended an invitation to Judge Howard J. Reeder, who retires from the bench, to partake of a complimentary dinner, and the invitation has been accepted. The dinner will take place Friday evening at the United States Hotel. A number of prominent gentlemen outside the Bar will be present and Judge Henry Green, of the State Supreme Court, will preside.

Miss Margaret Gandy, a daughter of Mr. Sheppard Gandy, was married yesterday afternoon in Trinity Chapel to Mr. C. Lawrence Perkins. The ceremony took place at 3 o'clock, and was performed by the Rev. Dr. Morgan Dix. The bride entered the church leaning on the arm of her father, who gave her away.

The Amateur Rifle Club held its annual meeting last evening at No. 7 West Thirteenthstreet, Col. L.C. Bruce in the chair. The annual reports of the Treasurer and Secretary were read, and showed the club to be in a flourishing financial condition, with a membership of 75 persons.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 17.--The annual product of precious metals in the States and Territories west of the Missouri River, including British Columbia, and the receipts at San Francisco from the west coast of Mexico, reported to Wells, Fargo Co., are as follows: Gold, $31,869,686; silver, $45,077,829. William H. Thompson Co., the agents of the missing steam-ship City of London, still profess to entertain some hopes that she is afloat, but the latest advices from Fayal, in the Azores, bring no bidings of her, and there is little doubt that she has been lost with all hands on board.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--William B. Stevenson, head book-keeper at Disston's Saw Works at Tacony, has disappeared, and an examination of his books shows a deficiency of $4,000. It is believed that he has eloped with Miss Nellie Stanton, of Tacony, as the pair were last seen at the railway station last Saturday. Stevenson is a married man 40 years of age. The girl is 18 years old.

The Alumni of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in general, and those residing in this City in particular, enjoyed their second annual "re-union banquet" last evening in the Hoffman House. Not all the graduates of the institute were there by any means, but those who did take part in the affair would like to have an "annual" banquet about once every week.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--The history of the claim of Danford Mott shows how long it takes a claimant to get his money, even after the Court of Claims has rendered a judgment in his favor.
BERLIN, Jan. 17.--The specie in the Im perial Bank of Germany has increased 6,232, 000 marks since the last report.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 17.--The Spring meet ing of the Savannah Jockey Club opened to-day. The weather was favorable, but the attendance was small and consisted mostly of sporting men.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 17.--To-day's session of the fourth of the series of agricultural conventions was opened by the reading of a paper on "Viticulture in California" by Mr. H.F. Page, of California. Many of the delegates participated in the debate which followed the reading of this paper. The author dwelt at some length on the exemption from phylloxera which is a characteristic of the California vine. The series of conventions will end to-morrow.
There were 221 missent letters received at the general Post Office on Monday in mails received that day from steamers just arrived from Europe.

ALBANY, Jan. 17.--Clarkson N. Potter, who is here in attendance at the Court of Appeals, was this afternoon suddenly taken ill, and is confined to his room in the Delavan House. It is said that he was attacked by a fit of nervous prostration. The doctors to night state that he is improved.

Maurice E. Barriere, a young man recently employed as a clerk in the jewelry store of Mrs. Theresa Lynch, No. 925 Broadway, was arrested yesterday by Officers Kelly and McSally, of the Jefferson Market Police Court, charged with stealing from the store.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 17.--The anthracite coal interests have agreed to the stoppage of coalmining on Jan. 19, 20, and 21.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jan. 17.--The Government has accepted, for the use of the Navy, the Lay tor pedo, which was experimented with by the officers of the torpedo station here last Summer.

The Board of Trustees of the College of the City of New-York met yesterday afternoon and reelected Stephen A. Walker Chairman for the ensuing year. WASHINGTON, Jan. 17, 1882. The national bank notes received for redemption to-day amounted to $481,000.

TORONTO, Ontario, Jan. 17.--Commander Cheyne will leave here to-day for Ottawa. He says he has received hearty support from all shades of politics, and expects no opposition to a Government grant for his expedition to the arctic regions.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 18.--In the State Legislature to-day a concurrent resolution relating to the death of President Garfield passed both houses. McGill was elected United States Senator for the short term.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 18.--The second day's races of the Jockey Club were fairly attended, but the weather was unfavorable. Four of the horses entered in the different races were withdrawn on account of lameness.

BOSTON, Jan. 18.--A dispatch received here says that the bark Mauhegan, Capt. Luce, which sailed from Montevido, Oct. 13, 1881, was at Newcastle, New South Wales, previous to Jan. 16, and had been so badly damaged by fire that she would probably be condemned. CINCINNATI, Jan. 19.--The auction sale of choice of seats for the Opera Festival continued today. College Hall was full of people, and the bidding continued to be spirited. There was 1,028 more seats sold, for which an aggregate of $24,781 were received.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 19.--It is stated that the sugar refining firm of Eccles, Thoms Co., whose refinery at Canton was damaged by fire in December last, has become embarrassed and submitted a proposition to its creditors to pay 50 cents on the dollar, in four, eight, and twelve months. The liabilities are placed at $67,000.

TOM'S RIVER, N.J., Jan. 19.--The Ocean County National Bank, at this place, surrendered its charter 11 months ago, and went into liquidation. Indirect taxes in France for the year just ended have surpassed the estimates by 216,739,000f., or a sum which, added to the estimates, corresponds with the yield of 1879. NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 20.--At 2 o'clock this morning the Cumberland River came to a stand, and continued stationary four hours, after which it commenced falling, and up to 8 o'clock to-night had declined over two inches. Rain has fallen steadily all day, and fears of another rise are entertained. It has now rained for 17 days.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20.--The Executive Committee of the National Board of Health, at its meeting this afternoon, declared small-pox to be epidemic in the United States. CHICAGO, Jan. 20.--During the past two months a controversy has existed between Dr. Carver and Capt. Bogardus over the title of champion wing shot of the world. Both lay claim to it and both are willing to enter a match to decide the question. A hitch, however, now exists as to where the contest shall take place.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Jan. 20.--The Coroner's jury in the case of Bridget Shedecker, accused of poisoning her husband, Benedict, in Dover, has rendered a verdict finding her guilty of willful and malicious murder. SING SING, N.Y., Jan. 21.--At an early hour this morning Mary Harrington, a servant in the employ of James Ostrander, of Tarrytown, jumped out of a two-story window in her night clothes, ran swiftly down to the river and plunged in. INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 21.,--Indianapolis advances in a steady progression. In December, 1881, more than 30,000 more letters were delivered than during the same month in 1880. A dispatch from St. Paul, Minn., printed in THE TIMES yesterday, gave the details of a transaction whereby the Chicago, Portage and Lake Superior Railroad, an uncompleted line, was turned over to the control of another corporation--the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis and Omaha Railroad Company. There were suggestions of crookedness, and it was intimated that the first named road was simply a paper concern.
